title: Microgravity accelerates skeletal muscle degeneration
summary: Astronauts exposed to microgravity may lose significant skeletal muscle mass and strength over time, as microgravity accelerates degeneration processes.

title: Current Knowledge about the Impact of Microgravity on Gene Regulation
summary: Microgravity alters gene regulation in cells, affecting proliferation, differentiation, and stress response mechanisms. The changes are observed across multiple biological systems.

title: Synthetic biology for space exploration
summary: This paper explores how synthetic biology can support life-support systems, radiation protection, and resource utilization for long-term human space missions.

title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: training and selection
summary: Overview of the Bion-M1 biosatellite mission and the mouse training and selection program; describes in-flight and post-flight in vivo and in vitro measurements and lessons for mouse welfare and experimental design.

title: Microgravity induces pelvic bone loss through osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and osteoblastic cell cycle inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
summary: Reports that 15-day microgravity exposure on the STS-131 mission caused rapid pelvic bone loss in mice, implicating osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and cell-cycle arrest mechanisms.

title: Stem Cell Health and Tissue Regeneration in Microgravity
summary: A review/analysis discussing how microgravity influences stem cell behavior and tissue regeneration, highlighting altered signaling, proliferation and differentiation in space conditions.

title: Selective Proliferation of Highly Functional Adipose-Derived Stem Cells in Microgravity Culture with Stirred Microspheres
summary: Shows that culturing human adipose-derived stem cells under microgravity-like culture with microspheres preserves stemness and improves proliferation and differentiation potential.

title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex qPCR analysis on the ISS (WetLab-2)
organism: E. coli and mouse liver tissue (validation samples)
summary: Describes the validation of WetLab-2, a suite for on-orbit RNA extraction and multiplex qPCR, demonstrating reliable gene expression measurements in microgravity.

title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress, Trp53, and Senescence Pathways in Cardiac Tissue
summary: Reports that short-duration spaceflight alters gene expression related to oxidative stress, cell cycle and senescence in mouse cardiac tissue.

title: Dose- and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
summary: Explores how different ion types and doses impact oxidative stress responses in bone, with implications for long-term skeletal health after space radiation exposure.

title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions
summary: Overview of NASA life sciences translational research efforts and examples of early-stage work aimed at supporting human exploration and mission operations.

title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebral bodies
summary: Describes a precise ex vivo cyclic loading method for small-animal vertebral bodies to study bone mechanical responses.

title: Effects of Ex Vivo Ionizing Radiation on Collagen Structure and the Mechanical Behavior of Bone
summary: Shows that ionizing radiation alters collagen architecture and mechanical properties of bone tissue in ex vivo experiments.

title: Absence of γ-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 signaling to mechanical load
summary: Examines mechanotransduction changes when γ-sarcoglycan is absent, using muscle cell and tissue models to probe p70S6 signaling under load.

title: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have overlapping functions in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Functional genetics study showing overlapping roles of RabD small GTPases in plant trafficking and development.

title: TNO1 is involved in salt tolerance and vacuolar trafficking in Arabidopsis
summary: Characterizes the TNO1 protein and its roles in vacuolar trafficking and salt-stress tolerance in Arabidopsis.

title: Identification of a novel Golgi-localized putative glycosyltransferase protein in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Reports discovery and subcellular localization of a new Golgi-associated glycosyltransferase family member in Arabidopsis.

title: TNO1, a TGN-localized SNARE-interacting protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Shows that TNO1 interacts with trans-Golgi network machinery and affects root growth/ skewing via microtubule-related processes.

title: Gravitropism and lateral root emergence are dependent on the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1
summary: Demonstrates roles for the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1 in auxin transport and lateral root emergence, relevant to gravity sensing in plants.

title: The Drosophila SUN protein Spag4 cooperates with the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin
summary: Describes Spag4 function in spermatogenesis and its cooperation with Yuri Gagarin to maintain basal body-nucleus association in Drosophila.

title: Toll mediated infection response is altered by gravity and spaceflight in Drosophila
summary: Shows that gravity and spaceflight conditions modify Toll-mediated immune responses in fruit flies, indicating altered infection susceptibility under space conditions.

title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
summary: A multi-omics study across multiple spaceflight missions showing consistent lipid dysregulation in mouse livers after spaceflight exposures.

title: GeneLab Database Analyses Suggest Long-Term Impact of Space Radiation on the Cardiovascular System by the Activation of FYN Through Reactive Oxygen Species
summary: Systems-biology analysis of GeneLab omics datasets suggests space radiation impacts cardiovascular systems via FYN activation and oxidative stress pathways; integrates animal and human cell data.

title: FAIRness and Usability for Open-access Omics Data Systems
summary: Assessment of FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) applied to open-access omics repositories including NASA GeneLab; focuses on usability and metadata standards.

title: NASA GeneLab platform utilized for biological response to space radiation in animal models
summary: Analyzes GeneLab omics datasets from ground-based and spaceflight radiation studies to identify transcriptomic responses to different radiation types and doses.

title: Circulating miRNA spaceflight signature reveals targets for countermeasure development
summary: Identifies a microRNA signature associated with spaceflight across rodents and humans, proposing targets that could guide countermeasure development.

title: Machine learning algorithm to characterize antimicrobial resistance and virulence in the ISS microbiome
summary: Applies deep learning to shotgun metagenomics from the ISS to map antimicrobial resistance genes and characterize microbial virulence across sampled locations and missions.

title: Could Spaceflight Increase the Risk of Developing Cancer in Female Astronauts? An Updated Review
summary: Review examining how microgravity and space radiation may influence gynecological cancer risk, summarizing current evidence and knowledge gaps.

title: Muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression during spaceflight
summary: Transcriptomic study linking muscle atrophy phenotypes and gene expression changes during spaceflight, highlighting metabolic and DNA-repair related pathways.

title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence responses to ionizing radiation
summary: Describes how different radiation types (e.g., Fe, Si, X-rays) alter chromatin and DNA methylation patterns, affecting epigenetic and transcriptomic responses.

title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2
summary: Part of a multi-part review series on SARS-CoV-2 biology and clinical impacts; included in the dataset but not specific to spaceflight.

title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight
summary: Multi-omic analysis combining murine GeneLab data and astronaut data reveals molecular changes resembling aging and frailty after spaceflight.

title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key microRNAs
summary: Demonstrates that targeting specific microRNAs with antagomirs can mitigate radiation-induced damage in cell models and highlights potential countermeasures.

title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
summary: Discusses ethical, legal, and medical policy issues arising from commercial and non-governmental human spaceflight expansion.

title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model
summary: Finds increased virulence of Serratia marcescens after growth on the ISS and in simulated microgravity, with implications for infection risk onboard spacecraft.

title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility in Drosophila
summary: Shows cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress in flies reared in microgravity, indicating conserved effects relevant to human cardiac health.

title: Bundling up the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Primary Root Growth
summary: Review on actin cytoskeleton functions during root growth, relevant to plant responses to gravity and microgravity.

title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis
summary: Characterizes HLB1 function at the trans-Golgi network/early endosome and links it to actin and trafficking processes affecting root development.

title: ERULUS Is a Plasma Membrane-Localized Receptor-Like Kinase That Specifies Root Hair Growth by Maintaining Tip-Focused Cytoplasmic Calcium Oscillations
summary: Identifies ERULUS as a plasma membrane RLK that controls root hair tip growth through calcium oscillation regulation.

title: Brassinosteroids Inhibit Autotropic Root Straightening by Modifying Filamentous-Actin Organization and Dynamics
summary: Shows brassinosteroids modify actin organization leading to altered root straightening responses, relevant to gravitropism studies.

title: Cell type-specific imaging of calcium signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana seedling roots using GCaMP3
summary: Introduces cell type-targeted GCaMP3 lines to image calcium signaling responses in Arabidopsis root cell types, enabling high-resolution studies of signaling.

title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development
summary: Describes localization and roles of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR complex proteins in actin-mediated root hair development.

title: Impact of microgravity and lunar gravity on murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel
summary: This study investigated the effects of microgravity and lunar gravity (~1/6 g) on skeletal and immune systems in mice exposed for 25–35 days on the International Space Station. Bone loss induced by microgravity was largely restored under Earth gravity, and partially restored under lunar gravity. The thymus regained some volume lost in microgravity under Earth and lunar gravity, while the spleen showed gene expression changes under low-gravity conditions. The results suggest that organs have different gravity thresholds for maintaining tissue homeostasis.

title: S. aureus MscL is a pentamer in vivo but of variable stoichiometries in vitro: implications for detergent-solubilized membrane proteins
summary: The study re-examined the oligomeric state of the mechanosensitive channel SaMscL in Staphylococcus aureus. The channel assembles as a pentamer in vivo, while detergent type strongly influenced oligomerization in vitro. This indicates the physiological oligomeric state is pentameric and suggests that alternative stoichiometries observed in vitro are artifacts of detergent solubilization.

title: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve
summary: Researchers engineered the pore of the mechanosensitive channel MscL by introducing charged residues. This modification increased channel permeability to charged molecules, prolonged channel openings, and allowed release of larger solutes. The results show that internal charge modulation can enhance MscL performance as a controllable nanovalve, with potential applications in drug delivery.

title: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no variance in vivo
summary: Deletion of the C-terminal domain of SaMscL did not alter its pentameric state in vivo. These findings confirm that the pentamer is the native oligomeric state, while tetrameric forms observed in vitro arise from experimental manipulations such as detergent solubilization.

title: Three routes to modulate the pore size of the MscL channel/nanovalve
summary: This study identified three methods to reduce the pore size of MscL: truncation of the linker between transmembrane and cytoplasmic domains, crosslinking of the cytoplasmic bundle, and introduction of heavy metal binding sites. These manipulations decreased conductance and in some cases were reversible. The findings highlight ways to fine-tune MscL function for nanotechnology applications.

title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
summary: Using disulfide trapping, researchers mapped interactions between the S1 amphipathic helix and the cytoplasmic end of TM2 in MscL. These interactions changed between closed and open states, and cysteine substitutions altered channel activity depending on redox conditions. This supports a dynamic model in which cytoplasmic-lipid interface domains rearrange during gating.

title: The MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels act as microbial emergency release valves
summary: This review describes how MscS and MscL channels function as emergency release valves in bacteria, opening abruptly during hypo-osmotic shock to prevent cell lysis. It also discusses differences in gating, structure, and distribution of these channels, and their roles in microbial survival under environmental stress.

title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
summary: Chimeric MscL channels revealed that a single residue at the lipid interface (I49 in E. coli, F47 in S. aureus) controls channel open-state stability and activation threshold. This residue acts as a molecular spring, tuning both channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity.

title: Evidence for extensive horizontal gene transfer from the draft genome of a tardigrade
summary: Genome analysis of the tardigrade H. dujardini suggested that about 17% of its genes were acquired by horizontal gene transfer from bacteria, fungi, plants, and archaea. The study proposed that these foreign genes contributed to unique tardigrade adaptations.

title: Reply to Bemm et al. and Arakawa: Identifying foreign genes in independent Hypsibius dujardini genome assemblies
summary: This correspondence defends the claim of high levels of horizontal gene transfer in tardigrades, arguing that multiple independent assemblies consistently identified foreign genes, reducing the likelihood of contamination or assembly errors.

title: Tardigrade secretory proteins protect biological structures from desiccation
summary: Secretory abundant heat-soluble (SAHS) proteins from tardigrades were shown to protect liposomes from desiccation damage and increased desiccation tolerance in E. coli and Rhizobium. Structural modeling suggests SAHS proteins undergo conformational changes upon water loss that help stabilize biological structures.

title: Desiccation of Hypsibius exemplaris
summary: This protocol describes stepwise desiccation of H. exemplaris tardigrades to induce anhydrobiosis while maintaining viability. The procedure enables controlled studies of desiccation tolerance and long-term preservation of animals in a dry state.

title: Possible roles of CAHS proteins from Tardigrade in osmotic stress tolerance in mammalian cells
summary: CAHS proteins from tardigrades were expressed in mammalian cells exposed to hyperosmotic stress. These proteins improved cell survival under osmotic stress, suggesting CAHS proteins can mitigate cellular damage from water loss and enhance stress tolerance.

title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
summary: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) increased during desiccation-induced anhydrobiosis in P. spatialis tardigrades. Antioxidant enzymes such as catalase and glutathione peroxidase were essential for recovery upon rehydration. Aquaporins also contributed to water transport during recovery, highlighting multiple protective mechanisms.

title: Partial weight suspension: a novel murine model for investigating adaptation to reduced musculoskeletal loading
summary: A partial weight suspension model was developed to simulate reduced mechanical loading in mice (38% body weight, analogous to Martian gravity) for 21 days. Mice maintained body weight but lost muscle mass and bone density, making this a useful model for studying adaptation to reduced gravity environments.

title: Partial reductions in mechanical loading yield proportional changes in bone density, bone architecture, and muscle mass
summary: Mice subjected to partial weight-bearing at 20%, 40%, or 70% of body weight for 21 days exhibited proportional reductions in bone density, bone architecture, and muscle mass. Even moderate unloading (70%) caused significant bone loss, showing a linear relationship between mechanical load and musculoskeletal health.

title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
summary: Electrical impedance myography (EIM) of mouse gastrocnemius muscle showed similar changes after 13 days of spaceflight or hindlimb unloading. Phase values decreased, corresponding to smaller muscle fiber size and reduced bone density, suggesting EIM as a useful biomarker for disuse-induced muscle atrophy.

title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
summary: Multi-omics analysis of mouse livers from several spaceflight missions revealed consistent lipid accumulation and dysregulation of fatty acid metabolism. Both transcriptomic and proteomic data showed activation of lipid metabolic pathways, suggesting that microgravity and space environment disrupt hepatic lipid homeostasis.

title: Treatment With a Soluble Bone Morphogenetic Protein Type 1A Receptor (BMPR1A) Fusion Protein Increases Bone Mass and Bone Formation in Mice Subjected to Hindlimb Unloading
summary: Female mice subjected to 21 days of hindlimb unloading received a soluble BMPR1A-Fc fusion protein treatment. Treated mice maintained or increased bone density and bone formation compared to controls, while untreated mice showed significant bone loss. The therapy enhanced bone formation and reduced resorption, making it a potential countermeasure for disuse osteoporosis.

title: RNAseq and RNA molecular barcoding reveal differential gene expression in cortical bone following hindlimb unloading in female mice
summary: Uses transcriptomic profiling of cortical bone from female mice after 7 days of hindlimb unloading; identifies altered expression of genes in Wnt signaling and metabolism (e.g., Pfkfb3, Mss51), highlighting novel mechanosensitive pathways in disuse-induced bone loss.

title: Proteomic and phosphoproteomic characterization of cardiovascular tissues after long term exposure to simulated space radiation
summary: Performs mass-spectrometry proteomics on mouse heart and plasma 8 months after simulated galactic cosmic ray exposure; finds dozens of altered proteins and phosphorylated peptides and strong perturbation of inflammation-related pathways (including increased neutrophil extracellular traps), suggesting lasting space radiation damage to cardiovascular systems.

title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
summary: Studies land snails (Helix lucorum) flown for 30 days in space; reports that spaceflight induced plastic changes in the snail vestibular system (altered geotactic behavior, statocyst gene expression, and mechanoreceptor responses) which re-adapted within ~20 h after return, demonstrating the snail’s compensatory response to microgravity.

title: Morphology of the Utricular Otolith Organ in the Toadfish, Opsanus tau
summary: Presents detailed anatomical analysis of the utricle (gravity-sensing organ) in adult oyster toadfish via light, SEM, and TEM; describes zonal organization (striolar and extra-striolar regions) of hair cells and afferent innervation patterns (each afferent contacting ~7–13 hair cells), providing structural basis for interpreting vestibular function.

title: Influence of Magnitude and Duration of Altered Gravity and Readaptation to 1 g on the Structure and Function of the Utricle in Toadfish, Opsanus tau
summary: Examines how oyster toadfish utricular afferents adapt to hypergravity (2.24 g) of varying durations and re-adaptation to 1 g; finds that afferent sensitivity first increases (after ~3–4 days) then decreases (with prolonged exposure 16–32 days), with recovery over days. Transmission electron microscopy showed no change in synapse counts despite functional shifts, indicating profound sensory adaptation without structural change.

title: Organization of the ER-Golgi interface for membrane traffic control
summary: Reviews the organization of COPI/COPII-mediated ER–Golgi trafficking; notes that while core coat complexes are conserved, the ER–Golgi interface architecture varies among eukaryotes. Discusses how COPII regulation and cellular context (mammalian vs plant cells) shape ER-Golgi structure to meet different secretory needs.

title: IRE1: ER stress sensor and cell fate executor
summary: Review of the ER stress sensor IRE1 in the unfolded protein response. Describes how IRE1 activation maintains ER function (via unconventional splicing of bZIP mRNAs) and can trigger apoptosis (through decay of anti-apoptotic miRNAs). Highlights both conserved and divergent features of IRE1 signaling in plants vs animals.

title: Inter-regulation of the unfolded protein response and auxin signaling
summary: Shows a bidirectional link between ER stress (UPR) and the auxin hormone in Arabidopsis: ER stress downregulates auxin receptors/transporters, and mutants lacking the ER stress sensor IRE1 have disrupted auxin signaling. Conversely, defects in ER-localized auxin transport reduce UPR activation. Indicates plant UPR co-evolved with hormone signaling to coordinate growth and stress.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum—shape and function in stress translation
summary: Editorial overview of ER architecture and dynamics in plant cells, focusing on its role in stress responses. Summarizes topics like ER network remodeling by myosins, ER-vacuole interactions, ER protein quality control, and ER stress signaling. Emphasizes the dynamic ER network's importance in adapting to biotic/abiotic stress.

title: Galactose-depleted xyloglucan is dysfunctional and leads to dwarfism in Arabidopsis
summary: Demonstrates that Arabidopsis mutants lacking galactose on xyloglucan side chains (mur3 mutants) produce dysfunctional cell walls and exhibit dwarfed, curled-leaf phenotypes. Defective xyloglucan accumulates intracellularly, whereas completely eliminating xyloglucan restores normal growth. Adding back galactosylated side chains (by gene manipulation) rescues growth, showing galactosylation is crucial for xyloglucan function and cell wall integrity.

title: Unfolded protein response in plants: one master, many questions.
summary: Review describing unfolded protein response (UPR) signaling in plants, its conservation with yeast/animal systems, and outstanding questions on how plants integrate UPR with environmental stress and development.

title: Vesicles versus Tubes: Is Endoplasmic Reticulum-Golgi Transport in Plants Fundamentally Different from Other Eukaryotes?
summary: Compares ER-Golgi transport in plants versus other eukaryotes, highlighting evidence that plants use tubular connections in addition to vesicle-mediated transport, raising questions on evolutionary adaptations.

title: Pectin methylesterification impacts the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth.
summary: Demonstrates that modifying pectin methylesterification affects plant growth and photosynthetic efficiency; mutants in PME-related genes show altered carbon assimilation and biomass production.

title: Reduced Chloroplast Coverage genes from Arabidopsis thaliana help to establish the size of the chloroplast compartment
summary: Identifies RCC genes as regulators of chloroplast compartment size in Arabidopsis; mutants show reduced chloroplast coverage leading to impaired photosynthesis and growth defects.

title: Maintaining the factory: The roles of the unfolded protein response in cellular homeostasis in plants.
summary: Reviews plant unfolded protein response (UPR) mechanisms in maintaining ER and cellular homeostasis under stress, highlighting plant-specific features compared with yeast and animal systems.

title: NADPH oxidase activity is required for ER stress survival in plants.
summary: Shows that Arabidopsis NADPH oxidases RbohD/F are required for ER stress tolerance, linking ROS production to unfolded protein response and cell survival.

title: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
summary: Analyzes transcriptomes of space-flown Arabidopsis seedlings, finding that UPR genes are consistently activated in orbit, indicating ER stress is a major driver of transcriptional reprogramming in spaceflight.

title: Reanalysis of the Mars500 experiment reveals common gut microbiome alterations in astronauts induced by long-duration confinement
summary: Metagenomic reanalysis of stool samples from the Mars500 simulated mission shows confinement-induced gut dysbiosis, with reduced beneficial taxa and altered immune/metabolic functions relevant to spaceflight.

title: High atomic weight, high-energy radiation (HZE) induces transcriptional responses shared with conventional stresses in addition to a core "DSB" response specific to clastogenic treatments
summary: Shows that HZE particle irradiation induces both general stress responses and a distinct double-strand break (DSB) repair program, differing from responses to low-LET radiation.

title: Genomic stability in response to high versus low linear energy transfer radiation in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Compares high-LET vs low-LET radiation effects on Arabidopsis genomic stability; finds high-LET causes complex chromosomal aberrations and higher mutagenic effects.

title: Acceleration profiles and processing methods for parabolic flight.
summary: Technical report on acceleration environments during parabolic flights, providing methods for processing acceleration data for use in biological and physical science experiments.

title: Cytoskeleton structure and total methylation of mouse cardiac and lung tissue during space flight.
summary: Examines cardiac and lung tissues from mice flown on Bion-M1; finds cytoskeleton disorganization and altered DNA methylation, suggesting epigenetic remodeling in space.

title: Toward countering muscle and bone loss with spaceflight: GSK3 as a potential target
summary: Reviews evidence that glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK3) is a key regulator of muscle and bone catabolism in spaceflight, proposing pharmacologic inhibition as a countermeasure.

title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leak and this cannot be counteracted with BuOE treatment
summary: Finds that spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leak in skeletal muscle; treatment with antioxidant BuOE does not prevent this, indicating oxidative stress-independent mechanisms.

title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties
summary: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured on ISS show delayed differentiation and altered Ca2+ handling compared to ground controls, suggesting microgravity impacts cardiac development.

title: Inter-agency perspective: Translating advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments
summary: Perspective piece comparing biomarker discovery and countermeasure development in terrestrial vs space radiation environments, highlighting opportunities for cross-agency collaboration.

title: Genomic and functional characterization of Enterococcus faecalis isolates recovered from the International Space Station and their potential for pathogenicity
summary: Whole-genome sequencing and phenotypic assays of Enterococcus faecalis strains from ISS surface swabs show they remain non-pathogenic, despite carrying some virulence-associated genes.

title: Evaluation of in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight.
summary: Shows that spaceflight alters differentiation of monocytes into macrophages in vitro; cells exhibited reduced maturation markers and cytokine expression onboard ISS.

title: Identification of critical host mitochondrion-associated genes during Ehrlichia chaffeensis infections
summary: Identifies mitochondria-associated host genes that Ehrlichia chaffeensis manipulates during infection; includes genes linked to apoptosis, metabolism, and signaling.

title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites in adult Drosophila melanogaster.
summary: Demonstrates that E. chaffeensis can replicate in adult Drosophila tissues, validating flies as a model for host–pathogen interactions.

title: Development and characterization of two porcine monocyte-derived macrophage cell lines.
summary: Reports the creation of two immortalized porcine macrophage cell lines; provides characterization of morphology, differentiation, and immune responses.

title: Understanding macrophage differentiation during space flight: The importance of ground-based experiments before space flight
summary: Perspective discussing ISS experiments on macrophage differentiation; emphasizes necessity of ground-based controls to interpret altered immune responses.

title: Bone marrow leptin signaling mediates obesity-associated adipose tissue inflammation in male mice.
summary: Demonstrates that bone marrow leptin receptor signaling drives obesity-induced adipose tissue inflammation in mice, linking immune cells to metabolic disease.

title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
summary: Reports creation of DB-1, a murine macrophage cell line lacking leptin receptor; describes phenotype, proliferation, and inflammatory signaling properties.

title: Validation of methods to assess the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in tissues obtained from mice on the International Space Station.
summary: Validates high-throughput methods for sequencing antibody repertoires from mouse tissues flown on the ISS, establishing baseline approaches for space immunology studies.

title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing
summary: Characterizes naive antibody repertoire in mice via unamplified next-gen sequencing, providing reference datasets for studies on immune responses including spaceflight.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
summary: Reports that ISS spaceflight alters the diversity and usage of immunoglobulin repertoires in unimmunized mice, indicating immune adaptation to microgravity.

title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing.
summary: Compares sequencing methods for mouse antibody repertoires; concludes massively multiplexed PCR introduces biases not seen in unamplified sequencing.

title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
summary: Reports that skeletal unloading alters antibody repertoire responses to immunization in mice, suggesting unloading impacts adaptive immunity and vaccine efficacy.

title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the bone marrow antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice
summary: Analyzes how skeletal unloading influences the bone marrow antibody repertoire in immunized mice. Findings show altered clonal expansion and diversity of antibody sequences after tetanus toxoid and CpG treatment, suggesting mechanical unloading impacts adaptive immunity at the bone marrow level.

title: An analysis of the effects of spaceflight and vaccination on antibody repertoire diversity
summary: This study examined how spaceflight and vaccination affect antibody diversity in mice. By analyzing antibody gene sequences in the spleen and bone marrow after multiple International Space Station missions, researchers found a trend of decreased antibody repertoire diversity with spaceflight. The bone marrow B-cell repertoire was reduced after immunization, but specific gene usages remained similar between flight and ground animals. The findings suggest spaceflight subtly influences immune diversity, although results varied among experiments.

title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
summary: This study investigated the impact of a 37-day spaceflight on the reproductive physiology of female mice. The researchers analyzed the estrous cycle stages and ovarian hormone levels in flight, habitat control, and ground control groups. They found that mice in space maintained normal estrous cyclicity similar to controls. Ovarian estrogen levels were unchanged, while progesterone was lower in both spaceflight and habitat control mice relative to baseline. Ovarian gene expression showed minimal differences across groups. Overall, long-term spaceflight did not disrupt the estrous cycle or core ovarian function in these mice.

title: Effect of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is modulated by nutrient and oxygen availability
summary: This research assessed how microgravity influences the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa under different nutrient and oxygen conditions. Cultures of P. aeruginosa grown aboard space shuttle missions reached higher cell densities than Earth controls when phosphate was limiting and oxygen was limited. No significant difference was observed when phosphate or oxygen levels were high. Motility genes had little effect on growth outcome. The study concludes that spaceflight can increase bacterial cell density, but this effect depends on environmental nutrient and oxygen levels.

title: Spaceflight promotes biofilm formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
summary: This study examined biofilm development of Pseudomonas aeruginosa during spaceflight on the Space Shuttle. Compared to Earth controls, space-grown cultures produced thicker biofilms with higher biomass and live cell counts. Biofilms displayed unique structures with hollow voids not seen on Earth. These findings were consistent across multiple growth media and independent of motility. The results suggest microgravity conditions on spacecraft enhance bacterial biofilm formation, which has implications for astronaut health and spacecraft maintenance.

title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNA-seq data
summary: This paper presents a standardized RNA sequencing analysis pipeline developed by NASA GeneLab for spaceflight-related experiments. The pipeline performs quality control, read trimming, sequence mapping, and gene quantification to identify differentially expressed genes. It has been applied to multiple spaceflight transcriptomic datasets to ensure consistent analysis methods. By making the pipeline and resulting processed datasets publicly available, the work enhances transparency and enables researchers to reproducibly study gene expression changes due to spaceflight across different experiments.

title: NASA GeneLab: interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
summary: This article describes updates to the NASA GeneLab platform, a repository for spaceflight omics (genomic, proteomic, metabolomic) data. The authors discuss new web interfaces (including the GEODE tool), improved metadata curation, and application programming interfaces (APIs) to facilitate data access. Enhancements also include support for visualization tools and community feedback mechanisms. The goal is to help researchers easily explore and analyze datasets from space biology experiments, promoting data reuse and discovery in the space life sciences community.

title: Comprehensive multi-omics analysis reveals mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact
summary: This study integrated multiple omics data (transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, epigenomics) from NASA astronaut samples and rodent models to identify common biological pathways affected by spaceflight. The analysis found that mitochondrial processes were consistently disrupted across datasets, suggesting mitochondrial dysfunction as a key response to space travel. Other impacted pathways included immune signaling, inflammation, cell cycle, and circadian rhythm. Data from the NASA Twin Study supported these findings. The results highlight mitochondrial stress as a central hub of spaceflight-induced molecular changes.

title: A new era for space life science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
summary: This paper introduces the International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP) consortium, which aims to standardize methods across international space biology projects. The authors review current challenges in spaceflight omics (genomics, proteomics, metabolomics) and emphasize the need for common protocols, metadata reporting, and quality standards. They discuss guidelines for sample collection, data management, and sharing to ensure interoperability of space life science data. The ISSOP initiative seeks to harmonize efforts across agencies to improve reproducibility and integration of omics research in space.

title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
summary: This study linked gene expression changes in space-flown mice to human disease phenotypes using a biomedical knowledge graph (SPOKE). By integrating transcriptomic data from six GeneLab mouse studies into the network, researchers identified symptom and disease nodes enriched during spaceflight. The method revealed key pathways and physiological changes, effectively mapping molecular alterations from spaceflight to potential terrestrial health outcomes. The findings provide insight into how space-induced molecular signals might translate to clinical symptoms, bridging animal data and human health risks.

title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNA-seq data
summary: This resource paper details a standardized analysis pipeline for spaceflight RNA sequencing data developed by NASA GeneLab. It includes steps like sequence quality control, adapter trimming, alignment to reference genomes, and quantification of gene expression. The pipeline is applied to multiple space-related datasets, producing harmonized lists of differentially expressed genes. By providing both the workflow and processed results publicly, the study promotes reproducible data analysis and helps researchers to reliably compare gene expression across different space biology experiments.

title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
summary: This study used an integrated spatial multiomics approach to investigate how spaceflight affects the mouse brain. Combining single-cell RNA sequencing, chromatin accessibility profiling, and spatial transcriptomics, the authors mapped cellular and regional brain changes after long-term spaceflight. Results showed altered neurogenesis, synapse formation, and neurotransmission in cortex, hippocampus, and other areas. Activated astrocytes and immune signatures were observed. Some spaceflight-induced changes resembled neurodegenerative processes. This high-resolution analysis highlights specific brain regions and pathways affected by space travel.

title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos
summary: This commentary advocates for open science principles in space biology research. It emphasizes that spaceflight experiments are rare and costly, making data sharing crucial. The authors highlight efforts like NASA’s open-access GeneLab repository and discuss the importance of transparent data release for enabling broader research. They argue that international collaboration and open data accelerate discovery and innovation in the life sciences in space. The article calls on the community to continue pioneering open science to maximize the value of space research investments.

title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
summary: This paper introduces the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) entry for the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. It describes how researchers can access the comprehensive biological datasets collected from the civilian astronauts, including omics and clinical data. The authors discuss the establishment of data standards and provide an overview of programmatic access methods (e.g., APIs) for these resources. The goal is to facilitate longitudinal, multimodal analysis of how commercial spaceflight affects human health, setting a model for future open-access post-mission data sharing.

title: NASA GeneLab derived microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens organisms in altered gravitational conditions
summary: This review compares gene expression changes observed in microarray datasets for mice and humans exposed to microgravity or other altered gravity conditions. By mining the NASA GeneLab repository, the authors identify genes that are consistently affected across different studies. They note overlaps in differentially expressed genes within musculoskeletal tissues of mice and highlight a limited overlap between mouse and human responses, likely due to fewer human samples. The comparative meta-analysis demonstrates the value of shared open data for uncovering reproducible biological mechanisms in spaceflight experiments.

title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
summary: This editorial commemorates key anniversaries of NASA data programs: 30 years of the Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and 10 years of the GeneLab project. The authors review the history of NASA life sciences research from Skylab through the ISS, noting that vast amounts of experimental data have been collected. These legacy datasets are now publicly available, enabling the scientific community to explore them for new discoveries. The article emphasizes that this open access to decades of spaceflight data is a milestone for advancing space biology and exploration.

title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice
summary: This study investigated how the absence of caveolae (small membrane invaginations) affects lymphatic fluid transport in mice. Mice lacking the caveolin-1 protein (and thus caveolae) showed increased tissue uptake of fluid and macromolecules, but reduced lymph flow toward draining lymph nodes. The reduced lymphatic pumping was linked to impaired vessel contractility, partly restored by inhibiting nitric oxide. These results reveal that caveolae in lymphatic endothelium regulate two opposing aspects: they normally limit tissue fluid uptake while supporting rhythmic lymph propulsion. The study highlights caveolae as a key regulator of lymphatic transport.

title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on earth and in space
summary: This research compared fungal and bacterial communities in dust from Earth homes and the International Space Station (ISS). The study found that Earth-based indoor environments harbored a richer fungal diversity (more species) than the ISS environment. When the dust samples were subjected to elevated moisture in laboratory conditions, the fungal community composition changed significantly at higher humidity levels. These findings suggest that closed habitats like the ISS have distinct microbial ecosystems, and that humidity can strongly influence fungal growth in spacecraft environments.

title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
summary: This study examined how different levels of humidity affect microbial growth in dust from the ISS. The authors exposed dust samples to various constant humidity levels and measured fungal and bacterial responses. They observed that even short exposures to high humidity caused a dramatic increase in fungal spore counts (up to four orders of magnitude) and reduced fungal diversity. Bacterial communities also shifted under sustained high moisture. A mathematical ‘time-of-wetness’ model was used to predict fungal growth under these conditions. The work highlights that controlling humidity is important for managing microbial risks in spacecraft habitats.

title: Aging and estrogen status: A possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
summary: Shows that estrogen influences vascular endothelial function and bone volume in female rats, supporting a coupling mechanism between endothelium-dependent vasodilation and bone remodeling:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

title: Chronic skeletal unloading of the rat femur: mechanisms and functional consequences of vascular remodeling.
summary: Chronic hindlimb unloading in rats reduces femoral blood flow during reloading and is associated with remodeling of the femoral nutrient artery:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

title: Differential effects of aging and exercise on intra-abdominal adipose arteriolar function and blood flow regulation.
authors: Robert T. Davis III et al.
summary: Finds that older rats have an impaired ability to reduce intra-abdominal adipose blood flow during exercise due to decreased vasoconstriction; exercise training restores vasoconstrictor function in aged rats:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

title: Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice.
summary: Spaceflight diminished vasoconstrictor responses in mouse mesenteric arteries and veins, likely via altered ryanodine receptor-mediated Ca²⁺ release:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

title: Spaceflight-induced alterations in cerebral artery vasoconstrictor, mechanical, and structural properties: implications for elevated cerebral perfusion and intracranial pressure.
summary: 13-day spaceflight in female mice reduced cerebral artery myogenic vasoconstriction and stiffness, and increased arterial diameter, suggesting elevated brain blood flow during spaceflight:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

title: Exercise training augments regional bone and marrow blood flow during exercise.
summary: Shows that exercise training enhances blood flow to multiple hindlimb bone regions during exercise in rats:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the vasomotor properties of the rat femur principal nutrient artery.
summary: Hindlimb unloading in rats does not change vasoconstriction of the femoral artery, but significantly reduces endothelium-dependent vasodilation, explaining decreased bone perfusion:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

title: Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms in the ZDF rat.
summary: In obese diabetic rats, long-term type-2 diabetes severely impairs endothelium-dependent vasodilation and increases vasoconstriction in bone arteries, reducing bone blood flow and potentially contributing to bone loss:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

title: Spaceflight on the Bion-M1 biosatellite alters cerebral artery vasomotor and mechanical properties in mice.
summary: Shows that 30-day spaceflight in mice reduces both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator responses in cerebral arteries, potentially limiting regulation of brain blood flow:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

title: Apollo Lunar Astronauts Show Higher Cardiovascular Disease Mortality: Possible Deep Space Radiation Effects on the Vascular Endothelium.
summary: Finds Apollo lunar astronauts have a much higher CVD mortality (43%) than other astronauts, and that simulated deep-space radiation induces long-term endothelial dysfunction in mice:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}.

title: Effects of age and exercise training on coronary microvascular smooth muscle phenotype and function.
summary: Finds aging shifts coronary arteriole smooth muscle toward a proliferative, non-contractile phenotype and impairs vasoconstriction; exercise training restores contractile function and a younger phenotype:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}.

title: Impact of spaceflight and artificial gravity on the mouse retina: biochemical and proteomic analysis.
summary: Demonstrates that microgravity induces retinal endothelial cell apoptosis and alters retinal protein expression pathways, while artificial gravity counteracts many of these changes:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}.

title: Simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct neurovascular and structural remodeling of skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries in the rat.
summary: Shows hindlimb unloading produces opposing remodeling in rat forelimb vs hindlimb muscle arteries: forelimb arteries dilated and increased contractility while hindlimb arteries had reduced diameter and contractility, partly due to altered sympathetic innervation:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}.

title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina.
summary: Finds extensive DNA methylation changes in the space-flown mouse retina, with few gene expression changes; spaceflight also appears to slow the retina's epigenetic aging clock:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.

title: Development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail.
summary: Characterizes embryonic development of quail otolith organs: macular epithelium grows exponentially, hair cells appear first in striola, stereocilia polarization forms by E8, and mature afferent innervation develops by E12–E14:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}.

title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence in the rat thalamus.
summary: Investigates how vestibular signals from different sensory modalities converge over time and space within regions of the rat thalamus; suggests complex multi-modal integration in thalamic nuclei:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

title: Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals via the sympathetic nervous system.
summary: Vestibular lesions in rats cause significant bone loss in weight-bearing bones by reducing bone formation; this effect is linked to increased sympathetic outflow and is prevented by β-adrenergic blockade:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}.

title: Simulated microgravity enhances oligodendrocyte mitochondrial function and lipid metabolism.
summary: Exposure to simulated microgravity increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis in oligodendrocytes and altered secreted metabolites, indicating enhanced mitochondrial function and lipid metabolism in vitro:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

title: Simulated microgravity modulates differentiation processes of embryonic stem cells.
summary: Clinorotation of mouse embryonic stem cells disrupted cardiomyocyte differentiation gene expression, including inhibition of cardiac-specific genes and beating, indicating that simulated microgravity specifically impairs cardiomyogenesis:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}.

title: Impact of simulated microgravity on oligodendrocyte development: implications for central nervous system repair.
summary: Shows that simulated microgravity increases oligodendrocyte progenitor proliferation and motility, but delays their differentiation into mature oligodendrocytes (reducing MBP and CC1 expression):contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.

title: Space microgravity alters neural stem cell division: implications for brain cancer research on Earth and in space.
summary: Reports frequent abnormal divisions in human neural stem cells after spaceflight microgravity, including incomplete cytokinesis and multi-daughter divisions, which could have implications for neurological health and cancer risk:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}.

title: Oligodendrocyte progenitors display enhanced proliferation and autophagy after space flight.
summary: Finds human oligodendrocyte progenitors proliferate more after spaceflight, though some undergo increased autophagic death; proteomic analysis of the secretome indicated upregulation of stress proteins like HSP-90β.

title: Metabolomics profile of the secretome of space-flown oligodendrocytes.
summary: Space-flown human oligodendrocyte progenitors showed increased glutamate and energy metabolism during flight, and after flight displayed elevated mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}.

title: Metabolomic profiling of the secretome from human neural stem cells flown into space.
summary: Space-flown human neural stem cells showed increased glycolysis (pyruvate, glycerate) and amino acid catabolism (BCAA, glutamine), as well as increased NADH and spermidine production, indicating higher energy demands in microgravity:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}.

title: Strategies, research priorities, and challenges for the exploration of space beyond low Earth orbit.
summary: Review identifies seven research priority areas for biological studies beyond low Earth orbit, focusing on organisms and technology needed to address deep-space exploration risks:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}.

title: Spaceflight induces specific alterations in the proteomes of Arabidopsis.
summary: Proteomic analysis of space-grown Arabidopsis revealed significant changes: 256 leaf and 358 root proteins differed in abundance vs ground controls, mostly organ-specific:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}.

title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit.
summary: Space-grown Arabidopsis roots showed the normal vertical auxin gradient even in microgravity, indicating the auxin distribution is gravity-independent; spaceflight altered root cytokinin distribution:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.

title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways.
summary: Identified 11 candidate genes whose expression correlates with root skewing behavior under tilted growth conditions; these genes are involved in signaling pathways including sugar transport, salt, cell wall, and hormone signaling:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}.

title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana.
summary: SALK_084889 has T-DNA insertions in DREB2A and LOX1 genes; LOX1 expression is reduced under all conditions, while DREB2A expression is only affected by drought in roots:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}.

title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: are some responses dispensable for adaptation to spaceflight?
summary: Explored whether certain spaceflight-induced gene expression responses are non-essential: found that mutants lacking specific responses can still survive spaceflight without increased stress:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}.

title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_063500.
summary: SALK_063500 carries a lethal homozygous T-DNA insertion in AT1G05290; heterozygotes show abnormal siliques due to reduced pollen tube germination, and no viable homozygotes were recovered:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.

title: Utilization of single-image normalized difference vegetation index for early detection of plant stress.
summary: Demonstrates use of single-image NDVI to detect early stress in plants; can identify vegetation changes related to events like landslides or other stressors.

title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.
summary: Comparison of RNA-Seq and microarray data from two root zones showed distinct gene expression patterns; validates that both methods capture key transcriptional differences relevant to spaceflight studies.

title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Shows that Arabidopsis seedlings grown on the International Space Station exhibit distinctive alternative splicing patterns compared to ground controls, providing evidence that alternative splicing contributes to the plant’s adaptation to the spaceflight environment.

title: Biomass Production of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica During the 2018 Experiment Phase
summary: Reports the biomass yields of various vegetable crops grown in the EDEN ISS analog space greenhouse in Antarctica during 2018. The experiment produced about 268 kg of edible biomass (e.g. cucumbers, lettuces, tomatoes), providing baseline productivity data for long-term space-based plant cultivation.

title: Root Skewing-Associated Genes Impact the Spaceflight Response of Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Shows that Arabidopsis mutants lacking specific root-skewing genes (sku5 and spr1) exhibit different transcriptomic responses when grown in space, indicating that these pathways uniquely influence the plant’s adaptation to the spaceflight environment.

title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity
summary: Reports that after 30 days in microgravity (BION-M1 mission), mouse articular (joint) cartilage shows signs of molecular degradation (loss of proteoglycan, reduced expression of matrix genes) while sternal fibrocartilage remains largely unaffected, indicating different tissue responses to spaceflight.

title: Host-microbe interactions in microgravity: assessment and implications
summary: A review discussing how spaceflight (especially microgravity) affects interactions between animal and plant hosts and their associated microbes, covering genetic and physiological impacts on host health and immune responses, and highlighting the importance of maintaining microbiome balance during long-duration missions.

title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
summary: Shows that in the Hawaiian bobtail squid’s light organ, daily remodeling of the gut epithelial brush border is jointly regulated by environmental light and symbiotic Vibrio bacterial cues: dawn light triggers microvilli effacement (breakdown), while symbiont-derived signals (lipid A) induce subsequent microvilli regrowth, indicating a coordinated host–microbe control of tissue structure.

title: Symbiotic organs shaped by distinct modes of genome evolution in cephalopods
summary: Analyzes the genomes of the squid’s light organ and the accessory nidamental gland (both symbiotic organs) and finds that the light organ’s gene content resembles eye-related proteins (crystallins, reflectins), while the nidamental gland is enriched in novel squid-specific genes. This suggests the two organs evolved by different genomic mechanisms (gene duplication vs. gene innovation).

title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
summary: Shows that simulated microgravity causes the symbiotic bacterium Vibrio fischeri to release more lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and produce more outer-membrane vesicles than under normal gravity. These changes occur despite motility defects, suggesting microgravity affects the bacterium’s membrane integrity and physiology, which could impact host–microbe interactions in space.

title: Emergence of novel cephalopod gene regulation and expression through large-scale genome reorganization
summary: Reveals that cephalopod genomes underwent massive reorganization compared to other animals, creating hundreds of new tightly linked gene clusters (microsyntenies). Many of these novel clusters are associated with nervous system genes (MACIs), suggesting these genomic changes were instrumental in the evolution of the cephalopod nervous system and their unique morphological traits.

title: Modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression and caspase activity in the squid-vibrio symbiosis
organism: Hawaiian bobtail squid (Euprymna scolopes), Vibrio fischeri
summary: Under modeled microgravity conditions, both extrinsic (receptor-mediated) and intrinsic (stress-induced) apoptosis genes were expressed earlier and at higher levels in the Hawaiian bobtail squid. Caspase enzymatic activity in the squid host was also elevated under microgravity, but this heightened activity could be reduced using caspase inhibitors. These findings suggest that microgravity perturbs normal host-symbiont apoptosis signaling, although pharmacological inhibition may mitigate these disruptions.

title: In vitro generation of mechanically functional cartilage using fiber-reinforced scaffold
summary: This study engineered 3D collagen-agarose scaffolds reinforced with PVA fibers to grow mechanically functional cartilage in vitro. Using bovine chondrocytes, the constructs yielded high-quality cartilage tissue with increased glycosaminoglycan content and collagen deposition. Mechanical testing showed that fiber reinforcement greatly improved the tensile strength and stiffness of the neocartilage. These results demonstrate that fiber-reinforced scaffolds can support growth of robust cartilage tissue suitable for load-bearing applications.

title: Long-term evaluation of neocartilage formation in fiber-reinforced scaffolds under 3D culture conditions
summary: The researchers assessed long-term cartilage formation in vitro using fiber-reinforced hydrogel scaffolds seeded with bovine chondrocytes. Over eight weeks of culture, cartilage constructs increased in thickness, glycosaminoglycan, and collagen content. Histology confirmed robust cartilage-like matrix, and mechanical tests indicated the constructs developed high compressive modulus. These findings confirm that fiber-reinforced scaffolds can produce quality hyaline cartilage over extended culture periods.

title: The Goldengate microbiome standards for microbiome research: current status and step forward
summary: This report outlines the Minimal Information about any (x) Sequence (MIxS) standards for microbiome metadata. It provides updated guidelines for documenting experimental context, sample collection, processing, and environmental parameters. The authors propose standardized metadata fields to improve reproducibility and comparability of microbiome studies. Implementation of these reporting standards will support better integration and analysis of global microbiome data.

title: Spaceflight induces changes in the gut microbiota of astronauts and alters its interactions with the host
summary: Spaceflight significantly alters the interactions between hosts and their gut microbiomes. Analysis of samples from astronauts before, during, and after space missions revealed changes in microbiota composition correlated with immune and metabolic shifts. Notably, beneficial gut bacteria tended to decrease in abundance during flight, while inflammation markers increased. These results indicate that microgravity and related stresses perturb normal host-microbiome homeostasis, emphasizing the need to address gut health in spaceflight.

title: Host Asparagine Synthesis Supports Intracellular Parasite Growth under Nitrogen Limitation
summary: This study discovered that Toxoplasma gondii increases host cell asparagine synthesis to facilitate infection under nutrient-limited conditions. By reprogramming the host amino acid metabolism, the parasite ensures sufficient asparagine supply for its growth. The authors showed that inhibiting host asparagine biosynthesis restricts T. gondii replication. Thus, parasite-induced asparagine synthesis is a key mechanism enabling T. gondii survival in low-nutrient environments.

title: Comparative genomics of a new Cohnella genome reveals potential spaceflight stress adaptations
summary: Researchers performed comparative genomic analysis of a new bacterium, Cohnella hashimotonis, isolated from the International Space Station. The genome revealed unique genes potentially involved in stress resistance and secondary metabolite production. Notably, it contained adaptations that may help survival in microgravity-associated environments. This genomic characterization expands our understanding of bacteria that can persist in spacecraft habitats.

title: Metagenome-assembled genomes of microorganisms from the International Space Station
summary: Metagenome-assembled genomes from the international space station's microbial community were analyzed. This study reconstructed genomes of key microbial inhabitants of life support systems, revealing diverse bacteria with potential for biofilm formation. Functional analysis indicated presence of genes for desiccation resistance and stress tolerance. These insights help characterize the persistent microbiome in space habitats and inform mitigation of microbial risks.

title: Biocontrol strategies to modulate built environment microbiomes and reduce pathogen exposure
summary: This review evaluates biocontrol strategies to reduce pathogen exposure in built environments, especially in closed habitats like spacecraft. It surveys probiotics, microbial coatings, and environmental modifications aimed at suppressing harmful microbes. The authors highlight successful use of benign bacteria to outcompete pathogens in air, water, and surfaces. They also discuss knowledge gaps and propose approaches to maintain healthy indoor microbiomes and lower infection risk.

title: Extracellular ATP triggers and maintains systemic Ca2+ signaling in Arabidopsis
summary: This study showed that extracellular ATP triggers cytosolic Ca2+ increases in Arabidopsis root cells. Applying ATP to leaf surfaces elicited Ca2+ signals propagating to roots, suggesting a role for extracellular nucleotides in long-distance signaling. The Ca2+ waves depended on the TPC1 channel. These findings indicate that extracellular nucleotides can act as systemic signals, modulating intracellular Ca2+ in distant tissues.

title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
summary: Genetic analyses in rice identified a mutant (crw1) that coils its roots in water but shows normal growth in soil. The CRW1 gene was found to encode an ethylene-signaling component (OsEBF1). The OsCRW1-OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module regulates reactive oxygen species in the root tip, affecting auxin distribution and gravitropism. Importantly, gentle mechanical resistance (soil vs. water) activated calcium signals that suppressed ethylene signaling, revealing an interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing in controlling root gravitropism.

title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
summary: Genetic analyses in rice identified a mutant (crw1) that coils its roots in water but shows normal growth in soil. The CRW1 gene was found to encode an ethylene-signaling component (OsEBF1). The OsCRW1-OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module regulates reactive oxygen species in the root tip, affecting auxin distribution and gravitropism. Importantly, gentle mechanical resistance (soil vs. water) activated calcium signals that suppressed ethylene signaling, revealing an interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing in controlling root gravitropism.

title: Salt stress-induced Ca2+ waves are associated with rapid, long-distance root-to-shoot signaling in plants
summary: This PNAS study showed plants propagate rapid calcium waves in response to local salt stress. When Arabidopsis roots encountered salt, Ca2+ waves traveled to shoots at ~400 µm/s via the cortex and endodermis, requiring the vacuolar channel TPC1. These fast Ca2+ signals depended on ROS generation by TPC1, suggesting a novel long-distance stress signaling mechanism in plants.

title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
summary: Genetic analyses in rice identified a mutant (crw1) that coils its roots in water but shows normal growth in soil. The CRW1 gene was found to encode an ethylene-signaling component (OsEBF1). The OsCRW1-OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module regulates reactive oxygen species in the root tip, affecting auxin distribution and gravitropism. Importantly, gentle mechanical resistance (soil vs. water) activated calcium signals that suppressed ethylene signaling, revealing an interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing in controlling root gravitropism.

title: Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion enhances amyloplast dynamics in Arabidopsis zigzag1 hypocotyls
summary: In Arabidopsis hypocotyls, gravitropism relies on amyloplast sedimentation and vacuole organization. The zigzag1 mutant, which has fragmented vacuoles due to a defective SNARE protein (VTI11), is agravitropic. Treatment of zig-1 seedlings with wortmannin induced vacuole fusion, producing transvacuolar strands that freed amyloplasts to sediment. This enhanced vacuole fusion partially rescued zig-1’s gravitropic defect, indicating vacuole membrane organization is critical for amyloplast dynamics in gravity sensing.

title: A ROS-assisted calcium wave dependent on AtRBOHD and TPC1 propagates the systemic response to salt stress in Arabidopsis roots
summary: This Plant Physiology study combined modeling and experiments to explain fast Ca2+ waves in Arabidopsis roots. They found diffusion alone was too slow, but adding a reactive oxygen species (ROS)-trigger mechanism matched observed speeds. Indeed, inhibiting ROS production (with scavengers or in atrbohD mutants) slowed Ca2+ waves. Imaging showed systemic ROS bursts dependent on the RBOHD enzyme and the vacuolar channel TPC1, supporting a ROS-assisted Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release mechanism in rapid signaling.

title: ROS, Calcium, and Electric Signals: Key Mediators of Rapid Systemic Signaling in Plants
summary: This review discusses how plants use coupled ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals for rapid systemic communication. It highlights that stimuli like wounding trigger waves of depolarization, Ca2+, and ROS that propagate throughout the plant. Key components include NADPH oxidases (ROS producers), GLRs/CNGCs (Ca2+ channels), and membrane pumps generating electrical potentials. These intertwined signaling waves can induce hormone changes, metabolic shifts, and gene expression, enabling plants to mount swift whole-plant responses within minutes.

title: Real-time In Vivo Recording of Arabidopsis Calcium Signals During Insect Feeding Using a Fluorescent Biosensor
summary: This JoVE protocol demonstrated real-time imaging of cytosolic Ca2+ in Arabidopsis during aphid feeding. Using the GCaMP3 fluorescent indicator, researchers observed a rapid, localized increase in [Ca2+] around aphid feeding sites. This high-resolution assay quantified calcium dynamics in detached leaves before, during, and after herbivory. The system provides a repeatable method to study plant Ca2+ signaling in response to biotic stress with temporal precision.

title: Orchestrating rapid long-distance signaling in plants with Ca2+, ROS and electrical signals
summary: This review highlights emerging understanding of plants' fast systemic signaling. Beyond chemical signals, it details how ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals rapidly propagate through plant tissues within seconds. Key players include NADPH oxidases generating ROS waves, TPC1 and GLR channels mediating Ca2+ signals, and variation potentials carrying electrical cues. These rapid signals trigger defense and metabolic responses plant-wide long before slower chemical signaling can act.

title: Glutamate triggers long-distance, calcium-based plant defense signaling
summary: This Science paper discovered glutamate acts as a wound signal in plants. Damage causes glutamate release, which is sensed by glutamate-receptor-like ion channels. This triggers a fast, long-distance Ca2+ wave through the plant, activating defense genes in distant tissues. Thus plants use extracellular glutamate to link a local injury to systemic calcium-based immune signaling, analogous to neurotransmission.

title: Test of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome: A Discovery Environment to Explore Multiple Plant Biology Spaceflight Experiments
summary: This article presents TOAST, a database for Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptomes. TOAST integrates gene expression data from multiple NASA GeneLab and other space plant experiments into a user-friendly interface. Researchers can query gene-centric expression patterns across studies, visualizing known spaceflight responses (e.g., oxidative stress) and identifying new common trends (e.g., mitochondrial gene changes). TOAST thus enables comparative analysis of plant genomics in spaceflight conditions.

title: Tonoplast-localized Ca2+ pumps regulate Ca2+ signals during pattern-triggered immunity in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: This study identified vacuolar Ca2+-ATPases (ACA4 and ACA11) as regulators of immune calcium signals. In mutants lacking both ACA4 and ACA11, basal cytosolic Ca2+ was elevated and flg22-triggered Ca2+ transients had higher amplitude. These exaggerated Ca2+ signals led to immune-related phenotypes, which could be suppressed by high temperature or by re-targeting a plasma membrane Ca2+ pump to the vacuole. The findings show that tonoplast Ca2+ sequestration shapes calcium signaling during pattern-triggered immunity.

title: The Fast and The Furious: Rapid long-range signaling in plants
summary: This review describes how plants orchestrate rapid long-distance signaling via ionic waves. It explains that local stresses generate systemic electrical signals and Ca2+/ROS waves mediated by ion channels like GLRs, TPC1, and NADPH oxidases. These signals travel at cellular speeds, triggering distal defense responses within seconds to minutes. For example, wounding one leaf initiates Ca2+ and electrical signals that preemptively activate anti-herbivore defenses in other leaves before attack spreads.

title: Rad-Bio-App: A Discovery Environment for Spatial Transcriptome and Metabolome Analyses in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: This article presents Rad-Bio-App, a web-based discovery environment integrating plant omics and environmental data. It allows researchers to compare Arabidopsis transcriptome and metabolome datasets from radiation and microgravity experiments. Rad-Bio-App includes visualization tools to explore dose-response and identify shared stress-responsive genes across treatments. It aims to facilitate understanding of plant responses to combined radiation and microgravity conditions in space biology research.

title: Ca2+/H+ antiporter (CAX1) regulates plant response to submergence and anoxic stress in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: This study examined the role of the vacuolar proton/calcium exchanger CAX1 in plant stress responses. CAX1 knockout plants displayed altered calcium homeostasis and impaired responses to submergence and anoxic stress. The authors found that CAX1 modulates calcium signaling under low-oxygen conditions, affecting gene expression and survival. Thus, CAX1 contributes to plant adaptation by linking vacuolar Ca2+/H+ transport with abiotic stress signaling.

title: Meta-analysis of plant spaceflight and microgravity omics experiments
summary: This meta-analysis examined Arabidopsis transcriptome responses to spaceflight and microgravity. Integrating data from multiple experiments, it identified consistently regulated genes related to oxidative stress, cell wall modification, and light signaling. The analysis highlighted common pathways affected by spaceflight, such as photosynthesis and hormone responses, suggesting convergent adaptation mechanisms. It provides a comprehensive overview of genetic programs influenced by microgravity across different studies.

title: Effects of low-dose radiation on spleen architecture in relation to aging
summary: The researchers reviewed effects of low-dose ionizing radiation and aging on splenic architecture. They found that chronic low-dose radiation exposure in mice led to changes in spleen structure similar to those seen in aging, including fibrosis and altered immune cell distribution. These findings suggest radiation accelerates age-like deterioration in lymphoid organs. The paper highlights overlaps between radiation-induced and age-related tissue remodeling.

title: Radiation increases expression of osteoclastogenic factors in human bone tissue
summary: This study showed that ionizing radiation stimulates expression of osteoclastogenic factors in human bone tissue. Exposing bone samples to radiation increased RANKL expression and other markers that promote osteoclast formation. These molecular changes could contribute to radiation-induced bone loss. The results indicate that radiation exposure may accelerate bone resorption via upregulation of pro-osteoclast signals.

title: Protocols for low-temperature preservation of mammalian tissues during spaceflight
summary: This paper describes optimized protocols for preserving multiple mammalian tissues for spaceflight. It compares cryopreservation methods to fix samples effectively during space missions for later analysis. The authors demonstrate approaches for preserving tissues such as heart, brain, and muscle in low-temperature conditions. These methods aim to maximize scientific return by ensuring high-quality samples after spaceflight experiments.

title: The hindlimb unloading rat model: modeling effects of microgravity and disuse on the musculoskeletal system
summary: This review discusses hindlimb unloading as a rodent model for microgravity. It covers physiological effects on muscle, bone, and cardiovascular systems seen when rodents are suspended by hindlimbs. Key findings include rapid bone loss and muscle atrophy mimicking spaceflight changes.
