The authors outline applications of this model to study mechanisms of disuse and test countermeasures for spaceflight-related health issues.

title: Redox Signaling and Its Impact on Skeletal and Vascular Responses to Spaceflight
authors: Candice G T Tahimic et al.
summary: Review of how spaceflight stresses (microgravity, radiation) affect mammalian bone and blood vessel health through redox/oxidative stress mechanisms, summarizing recent insights and countermeasure strategies.

title: Influence of Social Isolation During Prolonged Simulated Weightlessness by Hindlimb Unloading
authors: Candice G T Tahimic et al.
summary: Examined effects of social isolation on 30-day hindlimb-unloaded (simulated microgravity) mice. Both isolated and pair-housed mice showed expected bone and muscle loss, but isolated mice had altered immune and stress responses (e.g. lower CD4+ T cells, different adrenal gland weight), indicating social context modifies weightlessness-induced effects.

title: Validation of a New Rodent Experimental System to Investigate Consequences of Long Duration Space Habitation
summary: Describes validation of a new rodent flight hardware system on the ISS for long-duration experiments. Female mice flown for 21–37 days appeared healthy, with only modest changes (e.g. increased thymus and liver weights in 37-day flights). Demonstrates feasibility of extended on-orbit studies with on-board tissue collection.

title: The role of alterations in mitochondrial dynamics and PGC-1α over-expression in fast muscle atrophy following hindlimb unloading
summary: In mice subjected to hindlimb unloading (muscle disuse model), fast muscle atrophy was linked to impaired mitochondrial fusion (downregulation of fusion proteins). Overexpression of PGC-1α (a mitochondrial regulator) preserved fusion proteins and prevented muscle loss, suggesting boosting PGC-1α can counteract disuse atrophy.

title: Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria mitigates changes in hippocampal cytokine expression following simulated microgravity and isolation
summary: Using mice overexpressing mitochondrial catalase, this study shows that simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading) and isolation alter hippocampal cytokine levels in wild-type mice, but these changes are prevented in catalase-overexpressing mice. Results indicate mitochondrial ROS signaling mediates neuroimmune responses to spaceflight conditions.

title: An extensive allelic series of Drosophila kae1 mutants reveals diverse and tissue-specific requirements for t6A biogenesis
summary: Characterizes Drosophila mutants in the kae1 gene (for t6A tRNA modification). Different mutants showed tissue-specific effects: loss of t6A led to blood-cell overgrowth (melanotic tumors) and growth defects in proliferative tissues (imaginal discs), while some strong mutants still achieved large body size. Highlights that t6A biosynthesis is crucial in dividing tissues.

title: Novel Organelles with Elements of Bacterial and Eukaryotic Secretion Systems Weaponize Parasites of Drosophila
summary: Discovers new venom organelles in parasitic wasps (that infect Drosophila) which combine features of bacterial and eukaryotic secretion systems. These hybrid organelles deliver virulence factors to the host fly, revealing a unique strategy by which wasp parasites suppress Drosophila immunity.

title: A combined computational strategy of sequence and structural analysis predicts the existence of a functional eicosanoid pathway in Drosophila melanogaster
summary: Uses bioinformatics to identify Drosophila enzymes analogous to the mammalian eicosanoid synthesis pathway, despite low sequence similarity. The findings suggest that fruit flies possess a functional eicosanoid biosynthesis pathway, challenging the belief that insects lack such a pathway.

title: Immune suppressive extracellular vesicle proteins of Leptopilina heterotoma are encoded in the wasp genome
summary: Shows that extracellular vesicle proteins (used to suppress host immunity) in the parasitoid wasp Leptopilina heterotoma are encoded in the wasp genome. Genomic analysis revealed numerous vesicle-associated proteins (e.g., proteases, immune modulators) confirming the genetic origin of its immune-suppressive venom components.

title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model
summary: Demonstrates that Serratia marcescens bacteria grown during spaceflight (or in simulated microgravity) become more lethal to fruit flies. Flies infected with space-exposed bacteria had significantly reduced survival. The increased bacterial virulence disappeared after culturing back on Earth, indicating reversible space-induced changes in bacterial pathogenicity.

title: A parasitoid wasp of Drosophila employs preemptive and reactive strategies to deplete its host's blood cells
summary: Finds that the wasp Leptopilina heterotoma uses two strategies to eliminate Drosophila immune cells: it releases venom vesicles containing immune-suppressive proteins (preemptive attack) and triggers host responses (reactive mechanisms). Together these strategies efficiently deplete the fly's blood cells and evade immune defense.

title: In Silico Analysis of a Drosophila Parasitoid Venom Peptide Reveals Prevalence of the Cation-Polar-Cation Clip Motif in Knottin Proteins
summary: Computational analysis of LhKNOT, a small venom peptide (knottin) from the wasp Leptopilina heterotoma, shows it contains a cation–polar–cation (CPC) motif found in antimicrobial proteins. This suggests the venom peptide may have antimicrobial or immunomodulatory activity, highlighting a conserved motif in venom knottins.

title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
summary: Reports that spaceflight alters interactions between Drosophila and its parasitoid wasps. After a spaceflight mission, host flies and parasitoids showed unexpected changes (e.g. in immune cell levels and infection outcomes), indicating that microgravity has complex effects on multi-species host–parasite relationships.

title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
summary: Reports that spaceflight alters interactions between Drosophila and its parasitoid wasps. After a spaceflight mission, host flies and parasitoids showed unexpected changes (e.g. in immune cell levels and infection outcomes), indicating that microgravity has complex effects on multi-species host–parasite relationships.

title: Simultaneous exposure of cultured human lymphoblastic cells to simulated microgravity and radiation increases chromosome aberrations
summary: Cultured human lymphoblast cells (TK6) exposed to simulated microgravity and ionizing radiation showed significantly more chromosome aberrations (both simple and complex types) than cells exposed to radiation alone:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}. This suggests that risk assessments based on 1G conditions may underestimate astronaut radiation risk and highlights the need to study radiation effects under microgravity.

title: Genes Required for Survival in Microgravity Revealed by Genome-Wide Yeast Deletion Collections Cultured during Spaceflight
summary: A genome-wide survey using barcoded yeast deletion libraries flown on the ISS identified genes critical for survival in microgravity:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}. Strains lacking genes for telomere maintenance were depleted in flight, and overall depletion patterns implicated mitochondrial and oxidative stress pathways. This indicates that microgravity induces DNA damage and oxidative stress effects on cells.

title: Effects of physical forces on the formation of Bacillus subtilis biofilms in space
summary: Giant baker’s yeast colonies grown under simulated (clinorotation/random positioning) and true spaceflight microgravity showed distinct stress responses. Both simulated microgravity and actual spaceflight enhanced oxidative stress and apoptosis compared to rotation controls:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}. These findings suggest microgravity and altered shear forces amplify cellular redox responses and programmed cell death in yeast colonies.

title: Effects of Space Flight on Mouse Liver versus Kidney: Gene Pathway Analyses
summary: Microarray analysis of liver and kidney from mice flown for 12 days on the ISS revealed common upregulated pathways despite tissue specificity. Both organs showed increased expression of genes related to hormone/peptide response, apoptosis/cell death, adipocyte differentiation, and negative regulation of protein kinase activity:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}. This indicates spaceflight activates shared stress and metabolic pathways across different mouse organs.

title: Yeast in Space
Behavioral and multiomics analysis of 3D clinostat simulated microgravity effect in mice focusing on the central nervous system
summary: Mice subjected to simulated microgravity (3D clinostat for 28 days) showed decreased spontaneous activity, altered gait and fear memory, and bone loss. Comprehensive analyses revealed brain transcriptomic changes in immune/endocrine-related pathways and altered serum/gut metabolites. These results indicate that clinostat microgravity induces neurological and metabolic changes similar to those seen in spaceflight:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

title: Three-Dimensional Kidney-on-a-Chip Assessment of Contrast-Induced Kidney Injury: Osmolality and Viscosity
summary: Using a microfluidic kidney-on-a-chip model, the study found that high-viscosity contrast media disrupted renal tubular flow and increased tubular epithelial cell damage. Elevated viscosity was shown to impair microcirculation in the kidney model, shedding light on mechanisms of contrast-induced nephropathy:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

title: The Effect of Different Concentrations of Epinephrine in Otoendoscopic Surgery on Surgical Field Clarity: A Double-Blind, Randomized Study
summary: This randomized trial compared topical epinephrine concentrations (1:5000 to 1:40000) for otoendoscopic ear surgery. All concentrations yielded similar surgical field clarity, but higher concentrations caused greater and longer-lasting hemodynamic changes:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}. The authors recommend using the lowest effective concentrations (1:20000–1:40000) to maintain surgical visibility while minimizing cardiovascular effects.

title: From the international space station to the clinic: how prolonged unloading may disrupt lumbar spine stability
summary: Quantitative MRI of six astronauts before and after 6-month ISS missions showed that lumbar lordosis (spinal curvature) significantly decreased (flattened) and active flexion-extension range of motion declined, associated with multifidus muscle atrophy:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}. Multifidus muscle loss, not disc swelling, correlated with spinal flattening. Combined with pre-flight vertebral endplate irregularities, these changes may underlie increased back pain and herniation risk post-flight:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

title: Fifteen days of microgravity causes growth in calvaria of mice
summary: Seven mice flown for 15 days on the Space Shuttle showed a significant increase in skull (calvarial) bone volume compared to ground controls:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. Calvarial bone volume and thickness increased in flight mice, suggesting that headward fluid shifts and the lack of weight bearing in microgravity stimulated bone growth in normally unloaded skull bones.

title: Altered disc compression in children with idiopathic low back pain: an upright magnetic resonance imaging backpack study
summary: Upright MRI of children with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) under increasing backpack loads (0–8 kg) showed that load compressed only the lowest lumbar disc (L5-S1). Compared to healthy peers, ILBP children had significantly less overall lumbar disc compression, reduced lumbar lordosis, and reported more pain with load:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. This suggests altered spinal load tolerance in children with chronic low back pain.

title: Spaceflight-induced bone loss alters failure mode and reduces bending strength in murine spinal segments
summary: Murine tail vertebral motion segments from mice flown 30 days in space had 17% lower four-point bending strength and altered failure patterns versus ground controls:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}. Flight specimens often failed through the vertebral growth plate, correlating with significant bone loss in epiphyseal bone. The results indicate that spaceflight bone loss degrades spinal bending properties, potentially increasing astronauts' herniation risk.

title: Spaceflight-Associated Vascular Remodeling and Gene Expression in Mouse Calvaria
summary: Mice flown on 15-day (STS-131) and 30-day (BION-M1) missions showed altered skull vasculature and gene expression. After 15 days of flight, calvarial capillary diameter decreased and capillary density rose ~30%. In BION-M1 mice, gene expression of pro-angiogenic VEGFA (15-fold) and osteogenic BMP-2 (11-fold) was markedly upregulated in calvaria:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}. These changes suggest microgravity-induced angiogenesis driving bone growth in non-load-bearing skull regions.

title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress
summary: Mycobacterium marinum cultured under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) exited exponential growth earlier and became more sensitive to hydrogen peroxide, with unchanged resistance to radiation or low pH:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}. RNA-seq showed hundreds of genes differentially expressed: LSMMG downregulated translation and metabolism, increased lipid degradation and stress response (notably sigma factor H):contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}. These transcriptomic changes imply that LSMMG mimics a nutrient-limited stress environment for the bacteria.

title: Effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism and signal persistence in flax roots
summary: Flax roots were reoriented and clinorotated to separate gravity sensing from mechanostimulation. Horizontal clinorotation (mimicking reorientation) increased curvature with higher rotation rates, while vertical clinorotation reduced growth and curvature:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}. The gravity signal persisted for ~120 minutes. These results suggest that mechanostimulation alters the magnitude of gravitropic curvature but does not change the persistence (memory) of the gravitropic signal.

title: Amelioration of the physio-biochemical responses to salinity stress and computing the primary germination index components in cauliflower on seed priming
summary: This study evaluated seed priming (hydro-, halo-, osmo-priming) in cauliflower under 100 mM NaCl salt stress. Salinity severely impaired seed germination, seedling growth, and photosynthetic pigment levels. All priming treatments alleviated these effects: primed seeds showed higher germination rates, growth, pigment and protein content, and lower oxidative damage compared to non-primed seeds:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}. Principal component analysis confirmed that PEG (osmopriming) treatments yielded the highest improvement in germination indices:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

title: Desiccation Mitigates Heat Stress in the Resurrection Fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides
summary: The resurrection fern Pleopeltis was tested for heat tolerance in dehydrated (dry) vs hydrated states. Dried fronds remained viable up to ~55°C, whereas hydrated fronds were damaged above 35–40°C:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. Dry fronds maintained photosystem II efficiency and antioxidant enzyme activity at higher temperatures. The data indicate desiccation markedly increases heat tolerance, with a ~10°C higher temperature threshold in dried tissues compared to hydrated ones.

title: Transcription Profile of Auxin Related Genes during Positively Gravitropic Hypocotyl Curvature of Brassica rapa
summary: Young B. rapa hypocotyls exhibit an initial positive (downward) gravitropic curvature followed by the typical negative curvature. Gene expression profiling showed that auxin transport/signaling genes (PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, ARG1) were upregulated on the lower (convex) side and downregulated on the upper side during the early positive bending phase:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}. After 48 h, the expression pattern reversed. This suggests the same auxin-related genes orchestrate both positive and subsequent negative gravitropic responses.

title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: results from a space experiment
summary: Brassica rapa seedlings grown in microgravity with high-gradient magnetic fields (HGMF) were studied. In microgravity, root statoliths (starch-filled amyloplasts) became larger and plant amylase gene expression was reduced, whereas clinorotation had the opposite effect:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}. This indicates that plants perceive true weightlessness differently than clinorotation, adjusting starch metabolism accordingly. HGMF was shown to induce curvature akin to gravitropism in space-grown plants.

title: Lipid Rafts and Plant Gravisensitivity
summary: This review discusses plasma membrane lipid microdomains ('lipid rafts') in plants and their role in gravity sensing and stress responses. Clinorotation and mechanical stress were found to enrich saturated fatty acids in rafts, increasing membrane rigidity and reducing permeability:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}. Lipid rafts connect to the cytoskeleton and mechanosensitive channels, suggesting they play a key role in membrane signaling and plant responses to gravity and mechanical stimuli.

title: Expression and characterization of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS in Xenopus laevis oocytes
summary: Describes heterologous expression and electrophysiological characterization of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS in Xenopus laevis oocytes, showing functional channel properties in the oocyte system.

title: United in Diversity: Mechanosensitive Ion Channels in Plants
authors: Eric S. Hamilton, Angela M. Schlegel, Elizabeth S. Haswell
summary: Review of the families of plant mechanosensitive ion channels (MSL, MCA, TPK), their functional diversity and roles in plant responses to mechanical and osmotic stimuli.

title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes
summary: Methods paper detailing protocols for heterologous expression and electrophysiological recording of bacterial and plant mechanosensitive channels in Xenopus oocytes.

title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing
authors: Elizabeth S. Haswell, Paul E. Verslues
summary: Perspective discussing current knowledge and open questions about how plants sense osmotic stress at the molecular level and candidate sensors/signaling pathways.

title: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex.
authors: Margaret E. Wilson, Matthew Mixdorf, R. Howard Berg, Elizabeth S. Haswell
summary: Shows that constitutive plastid osmotic stress in Arabidopsis affects shoot apical meristem differentiation, inducing apical callus through plastid-derived signals and ROS pathways.

title: Spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications within hair cells of the mammalian utricle.
summary: Ultrastructural study reporting increases in synapse density and synaptic plasticity in utricular hair cells after spaceflight, suggesting vestibular synaptic adaptation to microgravity.

title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration
summary: Shows that clinorotation speed affects hMSC morphology and motility: higher angular frequency reduces cell spreading and alters migration behavior under simulated microgravity.

title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization.
summary: Examines sequential roles of FGF-2 (promotes proliferation/growth-related genes) and BMP-2 (promotes mineralization-associated gene expression) in bone formation contexts.

title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer.
organism: Human (clinical study, men with prostate cancer)
summary: Clinical study testing lycopene and fish oil supplements in men on active surveillance; evaluated effects on COX-2 and IGF-1 expression as markers related to prostate cancer biology.

title: To Infinity and Beyond! Human spaceflight and life science.
organism: Human (review of human spaceflight life science)
summary: Review discussing human spaceflight biology, historical context and research priorities for understanding how spaceflight affects human physiology at molecular and cellular levels.

title: Hyperoxia inhibits T cell activation in mice
summary: Reports that hyperoxic exposure suppresses specific T-cell activation pathways in mice and that modulation of innate-like T cell subsets can alter lung injury outcomes in hyperoxia models.

title: Effects of gravitational mechanical unloading in endothelial cells: association between caveolins, inflammation and adhesion molecules
summary: Shows that simulated gravitational unloading alters endothelial gene expression: decreases adhesion molecules and inflammatory mediators while modulating eNOS and caveolin expression.

title: Fish Oil Increases Specialized Pro-resolving Lipid Mediators in PAD (The OMEGA-PAD trial)
summary: OMEGA-PAD trial found that high-dose n-3 PUFA supplementation increases pro-resolving lipid mediators in PAD patients, describing trial design and baseline characteristics.

title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates
summary: Analyzes gene-expression changes that accompany improved hepatocyte function in 3D aggregate culture versus 2D culture, highlighting pathways sustaining hepatocyte phenotype.

title: Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation
organism: Human T cells / immune cells (in vitro, spaceflight samples)
summary: Demonstrates dysregulation of microRNA expression in early T-cell activation during spaceflight, suggesting gravity-dependent control of immune regulatory miRNAs.

title: Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines.
summary: Shows that spaceflight reduces antigen-specific tolerance induction in mice and increases proinflammatory cytokine production, indicating altered immune regulation after flight.

title: From Cellular Mechanotransduction to Biologically Inspired Engineering: 2009 Pritzker Award Lecture
summary: Lecture-based review covering tensegrity, cellular mechanotransduction principles, and how understanding cell mechanics informs bioinspired engineering designs.

title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces
organism: Environmental microbiome (human-associated microbes on ISS surfaces)
summary: Shotgun metagenomic results show ISS surface microbiomes resemble crew skin microbiomes, supporting crew influence on in-flight habitat microbial composition.

title: Sierra Nevada sweep: Metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere.
summary: Metagenomic sequencing and culture of tropospheric bioaerosols across altitudes in the Sierra Nevada reveal taxonomic composition and vertical stratification of airborne microbial communities.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
summary: Reports draft genomes for 94 fungal strains isolated from the ISS as part of Microbial Tracking-2, enabling studies of potential adaptations to spacecraft environments.

title: Microbial Tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station.
summary: Comprehensive metagenomic analysis of ISS surfaces that characterizes microbial burden, species prevalence, resistome and functional potential over time and across locations.

title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
summary: Uses network and link-prediction approaches on spaceflight muscle gene expression data to nominate drug-repurposing targets for treating muscle atrophy induced by microgravity.

title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response
summary: Identifies a CD36-associated mitochondrial DNA/RNA fraction in plasma whose levels change with spaceflight, implicating mitochondrial dysregulation as a spaceflight response biomarker.

title: Increasing the Number of Unloading/Reambulation Cycles does not Adversely Impact Body Composition and Lumbar Bone Mineral Density but Reduces Tissue Sensitivity
summary: Investigates repeated cycles of mechanical unloading and reambulation, reporting limited adverse effects on body composition and lumbar BMD but altered tissue sensitivity to loading.

title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
summary: Finds that although exercise changes bone geometry measures, the bending strength index at the shaft was not significantly altered by exercise or unloading in the mouse model studied.

title: Focal enhancement of the skeleton to exercise correlates to mesenchymal stem cell responsivity rather than peak external forces.
summary: Shows that regional bone adaptation to exercise correlates with intrinsic responsivity of bone-marrow MSCs rather than simply the magnitude of external mechanical forces.

title: Cytoskeletal Configuration Modulates Mechanically Induced Changes in Mesenchymal Stem Cell Osteogenesis, Morphology, and Stiffness
summary: Demonstrates that the cytoskeletal arrangement dictates how MSCs sense and respond to mechanical signals (LIV), affecting osteogenic differentiation, cell shape and stiffness.

title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.
summary: Analyzes muscle and bone changes during mechanical unloading and reambulation showing variable loss/regain patterns and limited correlation between muscle and bone recovery across individuals.

title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.
summary: Shows that osteocyte apoptosis induced by hindlimb unloading signals osteocyte RANKL production that triggers cortical and trabecular bone resorption in mouse femurs.

title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation
organism: Mouse embryonic stem cells / embryoid bodies (in vitro)
summary: Single-cell RNA-seq study demonstrating that embryonic stem cells and embryoid bodies respond differently to gravity-based mechanostimulation, with committed cells showing distinct transcriptomic sensitivity.

title: Macrophages inhibit Aspergillus fumigatus germination and neutrophil-mediated fungal killing
summary: Using transparent zebrafish larvae, the authors show that macrophages form clusters around A. fumigatus spores and inhibit germination, which reduces neutrophil recruitment and neutrophil-mediated killing; germination rate differences explain strain-specific clearance. (in vivo host–pathogen interaction study).

title: Contributions of spore secondary metabolites to UV-C protection and virulence vary in different Aspergillus fumigatus strains
summary: Compares multiple A. fumigatus isolates and shows strain-dependent roles of spore secondary metabolites (including melanin and fumiquinazoline) in protection against UV-C and in virulence in a zebrafish model — protection/virulence effects vary by strain.

title: Regulation of hemocytes in Drosophila requires dappled cytochrome b5
authors: Kurt Kleinhesselink, Corinna Conway, David Sholer, Irvin Huang, Deborah A. Kimbrell
summary: Characterizes the Drosophila gene dappled (cytochrome b5) and demonstrates that viable dappled mutations cause melanotic nodules and hemocyte misregulation, revealing a role for cytochrome b5 in blood-cell regulation during development.

title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
authors: Joshua P. Vandenbrink, Raúl Herranz, F. Javier Medina, Richard E. Edelmann, John Z. Kiss, et al.
summary: ISS experiments show that in microgravity roots exhibit a positive blue-light phototropic response that is normally masked by gravity on Earth; red-light pretreatment modulates phototropic curvature and interaction with gravity is gravity-level dependent.

title: Recent transcriptomic studies to elucidate the plant adaptive response to spaceflight and to simulated space environments
authors: Aránzazu Manzano, Elena Carnero-Diaz, Raúl Herranz, Francisco-Javier Medina
summary: Review of transcriptomic datasets from plants grown in true spaceflight and in microgravity simulators; highlights common responses (cell wall remodeling, oxidative stress, defense responses, photosynthesis changes) and discusses experimental caveats and differences between true microgravity and simulators.

title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
summary: ISS experiments identify blue- and red-light phototropic responses in roots and hypocotyls that are modulated by gravity level; microgravity unmasks positive phototropism in roots and reveals interactions between light quality and gravity.

title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
authors: Joshua P. Vandenbrink, John Z. Kiss, Raúl Herranz, F. Javier Medina
summary: Review/perspective summarizing mechanistic links between light (phototropism) and gravity (gravitropism) signaling in plants, and how altering gravity (e.g., microgravity experiments) helps to decouple and study these tropisms.

title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
summary: Reports discovery of a positive blue-light root phototropism under microgravity and shows that red light and gravity magnitude interact to shape phototropic responses during spaceflight.

title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
authors: Christina M. Johnson, J. Z. Kiss, et al.
summary: BRIC-16 experiments (spaceflight seedlings) show differential regulation of hundreds of genes involved in cell wall organization, stress responses and plastid-encoded transcripts, indicating strong transcriptional remodeling under microgravity.

title: RNAseq Analysis of the Response of Arabidopsis thaliana to Fractional Gravity Under Blue-Light Stimulation During Spaceflight
authors: Raúl Herranz, Joshua P. Vandenbrink, Alicia Villacampa, Aránzazu Manzano, William L. Poehlman, Frank Alex Feltus, et al.
summary: RNA-seq from ISS fractional gravity experiments under blue light shows gravity-dependent transcriptional responses; microgravity induces broader stress responses that are attenuated progressively with increasing g-levels.

title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development
authors: John Z. Kiss, Elizabeth Wolverton, Kim van Loon, et al.
summary: Review comparing ground-based microgravity analogs (clinostats, RPM, magnetic levitation) with true spaceflight; discusses strengths/limitations of analogs and how experimental conditions influence plant responses.

title: The importance of Earth reference controls in spaceflight-omics research: Characterization of nucleolin mutants from the Seedling Growth experiments
authors: Aránzazu Manzano, Alicia Villacampa, Julio Sáez-Vásquez, John Z. Kiss, F. Javier Medina, Raúl Herranz
summary: Highlights the critical role of proper Earth reference controls in spaceflight omics studies and uses nucleolin mutants to show how reference conditions influence interpretation of spaceflight-induced transcriptional changes.

title: Effects of altered gravity on growth and morphology in Wolffia globosa
summary: Investigates growth and morphological responses of Wolffia globosa under altered gravity (simulated microgravity, partial gravity and hypergravity); reports small but measurable effects on growth rate and morphology relevant to using small aquatic plants as space crops.

title: Red light enhances plant adaptation to spaceflight and Mars g-levels
authors: Francisco-Javier Medina, Aránzazu Manzano, Raúl Herranz, John Z. Kiss
summary: Shows that red-light regimes can ameliorate some deleterious spaceflight effects on plant development and gene expression, and that light quality is an important variable for growth under partial gravity (Mars g) conditions.

title: EUK-134 ameliorates nNOSμ translocation and skeletal muscle fiber atrophy during short-term mechanical unloading
authors: John M. Lawler, Mary Kunst, Jeff M. Hord, Yang Lee, Kumar Joshi, et al.
summary: In hindlimb-unloaded rats, the antioxidant mimetic EUK-134 prevented nNOSμ translocation from sarcolemma to cytosol and mitigated unloading-induced muscle fiber atrophy and oxidative stress markers, suggesting ROS involvement in unloading pathology.

title: MnSOD overexpression reduces fibrosis and pro-apoptotic signaling in the aging mouse heart
summary: Transgenic mice overexpressing mitochondrial superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) show reduced age-associated cardiac fibrosis, oxidative stress markers and pro-apoptotic signaling, indicating MnSOD-mediated protection in the aging heart.

title: Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle
authors: Jong-Hee Kim, Yang Lee, Hyo-Bum Kwak, John M. Lawler
summary: Lifelong voluntary wheel running combined with mild caloric restriction reduced nuclear EndoG and other markers linked to apoptosis in aged rat plantaris muscle, indicating exercise+CR preserves muscle at the molecular level.

title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
summary: Shows that lifelong mild caloric restriction and exercise maintain sarcolemmal protein complexes and membrane-repair proteins in aged muscle fibers, protecting against sarcolemmic deterioration associated with aging.

title: The impact of SRT2104 on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and loss of muscle mass in hindlimb unloaded rats
summary: Evaluates the SIRT1 activator SRT2104 in hindlimb-unloaded rats and shows that SRT2104 preserves aspects of mitochondrial function and alters ROS production, supporting its potential to mitigate unloading-induced mitochondrial dysfunction.

title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: proof of concept
authors: Khaled Y. Kamal, Mariam Atef Othman, Joo-Hyun Kim, John M. Lawler
summary: Describes an engineered uniaxial cyclic-strain bioreactor that can induce hypertrophy (by cyclic stretch) and atrophy (by cessation), demonstrating a controllable platform for mechanobiology and spaceflight-relevant muscle studies in vitro.

title: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates from the potable water system of the International Space Station
authors: Hang Ngoc Nguyen, G. Marie Sharp, Sarah Stahl-Rommel, Yo-Ann Velez Justiniano, Christian L. Castro, et al.
summary: Characterizes Burkholderia isolates from ISS potable water flex lines; reports genome assemblies, phenotypic traits, and highlights these isolates as a distinct ecological niche within the Water Recovery System with implications for microbial monitoring.

title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
summary: Presents CAMDLES, a CFD–DEM agent-based modelling framework to simulate microbial growth, transport and metabolite exchange in artificial microgravity devices (e.g., RWVs), and compares predicted microgravity vs 1 g behaviours in community aggregation and mass transfer.

title: Hardware validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat on ISS: Canopy photosynthesis in reduced gravity
authors: Oscar Monje, Jeffrey T. Richards, John A. Carver, Dinah I. Dimapilis, Howard G. Levine, Nicole F. Dufour, Bryan G. Onate
summary: Validates the Advanced Plant Habitat (APH) on ISS using Arabidopsis and wheat; demonstrates APH's environmental control ability and reports canopy-level photosynthesis measurements under reduced gravity conditions.

title: Trimeric structure of (+)-pinoresinol-forming dirigent protein at 1.95 Å resolution with three isolated active sites
authors: Kye-Won Kim, Clyde A. Smith, Michael D. Daily, John R. Cort, Laurence B. Davin, Norman G. Lewis
summary: Presents the crystal structure of a plant dirigent protein at high resolution, revealing a tightly packed trimer with three putative substrate-binding sites and implications for stereoselective lignan formation.

title: Reduced Arogenate Dehydratase Expression: Ramifications for Photosynthesis and Metabolism
authors: Ricarda Höhner, Joaquim V. Marques, Tetsuro Ito, Yoshiaki Amakura, Karl Weitz, Kim K. Hixson, Laurence B. Davin, Norman G. Lewis
summary: Shows that reduced expression of arogenate dehydratase (ADT) enzymes alters photosynthetic performance, starch accumulation and secondary metabolism, linking Phe biosynthesis perturbations to broad metabolic and photosynthetic effects.

title: New insights into lignification via network and multi-omics analyses of arogenate dehydratase knock-out mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana
authors: Kim K. Hixson, Joaquim V. Marques, Jason P. Wendler, Jason E. McDermott, Karl K. Weitz, Therese R. Clauss, Matthew E. Monroe, et al.
summary: Integrates transcriptome, proteome and metabolome data from ADT knock-out lines to reveal systems-level rewiring of lignin biosynthesis, cell wall composition and related metabolic networks.

title: Functional consequences of radiation-induced oxidative stress in cultured neural stem cells and the brain exposed to charged particle irradiation
authors: Bertrand P. Tseng, Erich Giedzinski, Atefeh Izadi, Tatiana Suarez, Mary L. Lan, Katherine K. Tran, Munjal M. Acharya, Gregory A. Nelson, Jacob Raber, Vipan K. Parihar, Charles L. Limoli
organism: Neural stem cells; rodent brain (irradiation models)
summary: Charged-particle irradiation at low doses induces persistent oxidative stress in neural stem/progenitor cells and leads to cognitive deficits in rodent models; highlights mitochondria/ROS as mediators of radiation-induced neural dysfunction.

title: The Last Mile in Beta-Cell Replacement Therapy for Type 1 Diabetes: Time to Grow Up
summary: A 2025 perspective reviewing advances in beta-cell replacement therapy (stem-cell derived islets, gene editing, tissue engineering), discussing scalability, access barriers and proposing Quality-by-Design approaches to bring therapies to broader patient populations.

title: Network analysis of gene transcriptions of Arabidopsis thaliana in spaceflight microgravity
summary: Applies graph-based network analysis to spaceflight transcriptomic datasets to identify hub genes and network properties altered under microgravity, highlighting cell-wall biosynthesis, auxin response and stress-related hubs.

title: Detection of genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. responding to DNA damage from radiation and other stressors in spaceflight
summary: Identifies Arabidopsis genes responsive to DNA damage and ionizing radiation in spaceflight datasets, linking radiation-responsive pathways to other spaceflight stress signatures and suggesting candidate protective mechanisms.

title: The effect of spaceflight on mouse olfactory bulb volume, neurogenesis, and cell death indicates the protective effect of novel environment
summary: Examined olfactory bulb (OB) volume and markers of neurogenesis/apoptosis in mice exposed to spaceflight or ground analogs; spaceflight altered OB volume and neurogenesis, suggesting complex effects of the space environment on olfactory brain regions.

title: Effects of low-dose rate γ-irradiation combined with simulated microgravity on markers of oxidative stress, DNA methylation potential, and remodeling in the mouse heart
summary: Using a mouse model, the study tested hindlimb unloading (simulated microgravity), continuous low-dose-rate γ-irradiation, and the combination; combined exposure produced transient oxidative stress and changes in DNA methylation potential and remodeling markers in cardiac tissue.

title: Characterization of mouse ocular response to a 35-day spaceflight mission: Evidence of blood-retinal barrier disruption and ocular adaptations
summary: Mice flown 35 days on the ISS showed retinal changes including signs of blood–retinal barrier (BRB) disruption, altered expression of BRB proteins and increased apoptosis/oxidative stress markers — evidence of ocular stress after spaceflight.

title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae
summary: Ground-based analog study showing that combined chronic low-dose irradiation and modeled microgravity produce persistent transcriptional and functional changes in the mouse brain indicative of long-term neurological sequelae.

title: Spaceflight influences gene expression, photoreceptor integrity, and oxidative stress-related damage in the murine retina
summary: RNA-seq and histology from 35-day spaceflight mice reveal ~600 DEGs enriched for visual/perception and phototransduction pathways, plus photoreceptor degradation and increased oxidative stress — indicating retinal vulnerability to extended spaceflight.

title: Evaluating ocular response in the retina and optic nerve head after single and fractionated high-energy protons
summary: Compared single versus fractionated high-energy proton exposures in mice and reported increased retinal apoptosis and oxidative biomarkers after proton radiation, with some differences between single and fractionated regimens.

title: Characterization of gene expression profiles in the mouse brain after 35 days of spaceflight mission
summary: NanoString and transcriptomic profiling of mouse brain after 35-day ISS mission uncovered altered expression of genes/pathways related to stress, inflammation, apoptosis and myelin maintenance, suggesting neuroinflammatory and metabolic adaptations to flight.

title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity
summary: Multi-omics analysis (epigenome + transcriptome) after hindlimb unloading and/or low-dose γ-irradiation revealed time-dependent retinal methylation and expression changes; nucleotide metabolism and signaling pathways (Notch/Wnt) showed altered regulation post-exposure.

title: Evidence of spaceflight-induced adverse effects on photoreceptors and retinal function in the mouse eye
summary: Spaceflight induces oxidative stress and photoreceptor damage in mice; electroretinography showed reduced a- and b-wave amplitudes after flight and antioxidant (BuOE) partially mitigated oxidative markers, supporting oxidative stress as a mediator of photoreceptor injury.

title: Disturbances in human position sense during alterations in gravity: a parabolic flight experiment
summary: Parabolic flight study demonstrating that transient microgravity/hypergravity conditions alter human proprioceptive position sense (matching/pointing tasks), providing insight into how gravity changes affect sensorimotor perception.

title: Routine omics collection is a golden opportunity for European human research in space and analog environments
summary: Perspective/review advocating standardized, longitudinal omics collection for astronauts and analog participants across Europe (ethical/legal considerations included) to accelerate AI-driven personalized space medicine.

title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level
summary: Comprehensive review of spatial-omics platforms (single-cell to subcellular resolution), discussing workflows, trade-offs (resolution vs throughput), and analysis pipelines relevant to tissue-level functional mapping.

title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of fungal isolates associated with spacecraft cleanrooms
summary: Describes genomic/phenotypic characterization of fungal isolates recovered from Mars-2020 cleanrooms and tests for radiation tolerance; reports distinct species and discusses implications for planetary protection and spacecraft microbiomes.

title: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts with immune, cfDNA, mitochondrial, and telomere length changes during short duration spaceflight
organism: Human (Inspiration4 civilian crew; multi-omic human study)
summary: Multi-omic analysis of Inspiration4 crew: telomere length increased in-flight and shortened after return; cfDNA and immune signatures changed post-flight, but no evidence of persistent whole-genome instability or clonal hematopoiesis—showing mixed short-term genomic/immune responses to short-duration civilian flight.

title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
summary: Describes NASA OSDR access and programmatic tools for the Inspiration4 (I4) mission datasets — a guide for researchers to retrieve and analyze I4 multi-omic/clinical datasets available in the public repository.

title: Molecular and physiological changes in the SpaceX Inspiration4 civilian crew
summary: Comprehensive multi-omic and physiological profiling of the Inspiration4 civilian crew identified acute physiological and molecular responses to short-duration flight (neurovestibular changes, immune shifts, stress markers), most of which returned to baseline after landing.

title: Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to radiation-induced DNA damage and associates with telomeric repair
summary: Reports increased TERRA transcription following DNA damage from radiation across astronauts and other cohorts; provides evidence for TERRA accumulation at telomeric double-strand breaks and suggests a role in telomere repair responses.

title: Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
summary: Spatial multi-omic mapping of human skin samples from spaceflight-associated cohorts reveals inflammation signatures and KRAS pathway changes, linking space exposure to skin molecular changes with possible translational implications.

title: Longitudinal multi-omics analysis of host microbiome and environment during human short-duration spaceflight
summary: High-resolution longitudinal profiling of astronaut microbiomes and environmental samples during short-duration missions reveals shifts in microbiome composition, microbial transmission with the habitat, and correlated immune/metabolic signals.

title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space-associated multi-omic datasets
summary: Analyzes haemoglobin gene regulation across spaceflight multi-omic datasets (NASA, JAXA, Inspiration4) to identify developmental and spatial patterns potentially informative for hematologic responses to space exposure.

title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
summary: Single-cell multi-omic profiling of Inspiration4 PBMCs reveals conserved immune cell-type responses and sex-specific differences to short-duration flight, providing a cellular-resolution view of human spaceflight immunology.

title: Single-cell analysis identifies conserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
organism: Human PBMCs / simulated microgravity (in vitro) and validation with astronaut datasets
summary: Using single-cell genomics and validation across multiple datasets, the study identifies conserved immune signatures (monocyte activation, impaired T/NK functions, interferon pathway changes) shared between simulated microgravity and real spaceflight exposures.

title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank
summary: SOMA integrates clinical, molecular and multi-omic datasets from many missions into a harmonized atlas and biobank, expanding publicly available human spaceflight data to accelerate comparative and translational research.

title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
summary: Plasma proteomics and extracellular vesicle profiling of Inspiration4 crew revealed acute shifts in coagulation factors, oxidative-stress related proteins, and brain-enriched proteins immediately after flight, highlighting rapid systemic responses to short missions.

title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body: towards a Human Cell Space Atlas
summary: Proposes a Human Cell Space Atlas (high-resolution spatial and single-cell mapping in spaceflight) to guide precision spaceflight healthcare and to map how space exposure affects human cell states across tissues.

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations associated with skin health in spaceflight datasets
summary: Analysis of skin transcriptomic datasets from multiple missions identifies changes in DNA damage/repair pathways, mitochondrial dysregulation, and markers relevant to skin health — suggesting molecular drivers for skin-related risks during spaceflight.

title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
summary: Integrated multi-omic and morphological analysis suggesting spaceflight-related impacts on renal physiology and molecular signatures that may contribute to renal dysfunction in space-exposed subjects.

title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles across tissues revealing insulin and estrogen signaling alterations
summary: Cross-tissue analyses identify spaceflight-associated changes in insulin and estrogen signaling (notably hepatic insulin resistance/steatosis in mice) and related metabolic pathway perturbations that may have translational relevance.

title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed missions: leveraging genetics for astronaut health
summary: Review of genetic alleles that may confer protective effects (bone, muscle, cardiovascular health) and discussion of how genetic information could inform precision medicine approaches for crewed space missions, plus ethical considerations.

title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants (correction)
summary: Published author correction for a prior Commun Biol article addressing microRNA changes and potential spaceflight impacts on risk factors for small-for-gestational-age infants.

title: Growth chambers on the International Space Station for large plants
authors: Tatiana S. Aniskina; Kirill A. Sudarikov; Margarita A. Levinskikh; Alexander A. Gulevich; Ekaterina N. Baranova; et al.
summary: Comparative analysis of kernel quality traits for bread wheat grown under spaceflight conditions vs ground controls; measurements include grain composition and physical kernel metrics with discussion of implications for space agriculture.

title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station
authors: Christina L. M. Khodadad; Mary E. Hummerick; LaShelle E. Spencer; Anirudha R. Dixit; Jeffrey T. Richards; Matthew W. Romeyn; et al.
summary: Analysis of red romaine lettuce grown in the Veggie chamber on the ISS: microbiological plate counts, isolate identification and nutrient composition indicate crops were safe to consume and broadly comparable to ground controls under proper handling.

title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.
authors: Allison K. Strohm; Laura M. Vaughn; Patrick H. Masson; et al.
summary: Shows that natural variation in OCT1 expression modifies root-length sensitivity to exogenous cadaverine; QTL mapping and genetic evidence implicate OCT1 level in the phenotype.

title: Auxin: Shape matters.
summary: Perspective/commentary highlighting how auxin distribution and tissue geometry interact to shape organ form and growth responses.

title: Gravity signaling in flowering plant roots
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Review and experimental data on molecular/cellular mechanisms of gravity sensing in roots, including mechanosensing, auxin transport and hormonal crosstalk affecting gravitropism.

title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Describes how cadaverine impacts biotin biosynthesis to influence primary root growth; integrates genetic and biochemical evidence linking polyamine metabolism to root development.

title: Low-speed clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings triggers root tip curvatures that are reminiscent of gravitropism.
summary: Shows that specific clinostat rotation parameters cause root-tip curvatures similar to gravitropic bending in both species, informing use of clinostats as microgravity analogs.

title: New device for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Describes a microfluidic/flow device enabling high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms; validated on multiple bacterial species and compared to standard assays.

title: Sigma S-dependent antioxidant defense protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli against the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin
summary: Demonstrates that σS-regulated general stress response increases antioxidant defenses in stationary-phase E. coli and provides protection against gentamicin killing.

title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
authors: M. L. Hagan; V. Balayan; M. E. McGee-Lawrence
summary: Review of PMD formation and cellular repair mechanisms across mechanosensitive tissues (muscle, bone, brain), summarizing injury pathways and repair biology.

title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Analyzes protein expression and histology in mouse salivary glands after Bion-M1 and STS-135 missions; reports alterations consistent with stress/adaptive responses in glandular tissue.

title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Duplicate entry in dataset (same PMCID as pmc324); same article and summary applies.

title: Response of the mouse sublingual gland to spaceflight
summary: Ultrastructural and immunohistochemical study of mouse sublingual glands after spaceflight shows gland-specific morphological and molecular responses compared with ground controls.

title: Upregulation of Amy1 in the salivary glands of mice exposed to a lunar gravity environment using the multiple artificial gravity research system
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Reports upregulation of Amy1 in mouse salivary glands after exposure to simulated lunar gravity using a multiple artificial gravity system; suggests gravity-dependent regulation of salivary gene expression.

title: Reactivation of Latent Epstein-Barr Virus: A Comparison after Exposure to Gamma, Proton, Carbon, and Iron Radiation
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Compares effects of different radiation qualities (gamma, protons, carbon, iron) on reactivation of latent EBV in cell models; reports dose- and quality-dependent induction of lytic gene programs.

title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: 16S rRNA profiling of astronaut saliva pre-, in-, and post-flight shows compositional shifts during flight and explores associations with viral reactivation markers (EBV/HSV/VZV).

title: The AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module establishes a fast auxin-evoked Ca2+ signal that instructs root gravitropism
authors: N. B. C. Serre; et al.
summary: Identifies an AUX1–AFB1–CNGC14 module producing a rapid auxin-evoked Ca2+ signal required for root gravitropic bending, linking auxin transport to ion-channel mediated calcium signaling.

title: Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections
authors: E. D. Tichy; F. Mourkioti; et al.
summary: STAR Protocol describing quantitative FISH-based telomere length assessment in muscle stem cells within tissue sections, with validation and representative data.

title: Persistent NF-κB activation in muscle stem cells induces proliferation-independent telomere shortening
summary: Shows that chronic NF-κB signaling in muscle stem cells leads to telomere shortening independent of proliferation and links inflammatory signaling to stem-cell aging phenotypes.

title: Piezo1 regulates the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscles via orchestration of stem cell morphological states.
authors: N. Ma; D. Chen; J. H. Lee; et al.
summary: Demonstrates Piezo1 as a regulator of muscle stem cell morphological states and regenerative capacity; links mechanosensitive ion-channel signaling to muscle regeneration.

title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Examines combined effects of ionizing radiation and mechanical unloading on telomere length dynamics in murine skeletal muscle cells and documents recovery-phase changes.

title: Ethylene-induced flavonol accumulation in guard cells suppresses reactive oxygen species and modulates stomatal aperture
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Shows ethylene stimulates flavonol accumulation in guard cells, which suppresses ROS and affects stomatal aperture regulation — linking hormone signaling and antioxidant metabolism.

title: Transcriptional and Hormonal Regulation of Gravitropism of Woody Stems in Populus.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Review/experimental work exploring hormonal and transcriptional control of gravitropic bending in woody Populus stems, including auxin transport and cell wall modification.

title: Endosidin2 targets conserved exocyst complex subunit EXO70 to inhibit exocytosis
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Identifies EXO70 as the target of Endosidin2 and shows this small molecule blocks exocytosis by perturbing exocyst function, affecting cell wall and membrane trafficking.

title: A conditional mutation in SCD1 reveals linkage between PIN protein trafficking, auxin transport, gravitropism, and lateral root initiation.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Using a conditional SCD1 allele, the study links defects in PIN trafficking to changes in auxin distribution, gravitropic responses and lateral-root initiation.

title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 1: Intracellular overdrive for SARS-CoV-2 infection
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Review synthesizing intracellular host–virus interactions exploited by SARS-CoV-2, focusing on replication mechanisms and host-cell hijacking strategies relevant to pathogenesis and therapeutics.

title: Changes in nuclear shape and gene expression in response to simulated microgravity are LINC complex-dependent.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Shows simulated microgravity causes LINC-complex dependent nuclear morphology changes and downstream transcriptional responses linking mechanical inputs to gene regulation.

title: Growth of Carnobacterium spp. from permafrost under low pressure, temperature, and anoxic atmosphere has implications for Earth microbes on Mars
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Tests growth of permafrost-derived Carnobacterium under Mars-like low-pressure, low-temperature, anoxic conditions; shows survival/growth potential with implications for planetary protection.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi Strain WN1359T (DSM 27470T)
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Provides complete genome sequence for C. gilichinskyi strain WN1359 and discusses features that may support survival in extreme/permafrost environments.

title: Exposure of Bacillus subtilis to low pressure (5 kilopascals) induces several global regulons, including those involved in the SigB-mediated general stress response
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Transcriptomic study showing low-pressure growth activates global stress regulons in B. subtilis, including SigB-dependent genes — relevant to astrobiology and low-pressure physiology.

title: Resistance of Bacillus subtilis Spore DNA to Lethal Ionizing Radiation Damage Relies Primarily on Spore Core Components and DNA Repair, with Minor Effects of Oxygen Radical Detoxification
authors: Ralf Moeller, Marina Raguse, Günther Reitz, Ryuichi Okayasu, Zuofeng Li, Stuart Klein, Peter Setlow, Wayne L. Nicholson
summary: Shows that B. subtilis spore resistance to X-rays, protons and HZE ions depends mainly on spore core components (e.g., SASP, DPA, low core water) and DNA repair (NHEJ, AP endonucleases), while oxygen-radical detoxification plays a minor role.

title: Cultivation of Staphylococcus epidermidis in the human spaceflight environment leads to alterations in the frequency and spectrum of spontaneous rifampicin-resistance mutations in the rpoB gene
authors: Patricia Fajardo-Cavazos, Wayne L. Nicholson, et al.
summary: ISS-grown S. epidermidis showed altered viable counts and an increased frequency and a changed spectrum of spontaneous rifampicin-resistance (rpoB) mutations compared with ground controls, implying spaceflight-specific mutational stresses.

title: Experimental Evolution of Bacillus subtilis
authors: D. R. Zeigler (review/experimental article authors as listed on the paper)
summary: Reviews and reports experimental-evolution work in B. subtilis showing how laboratory evolution can alter sporulation phenotypes and other traits under selective regimes (thermal/pressure/UV etc.).

title: Cultivation in space flight produces minimal alterations in the susceptibility of Bacillus subtilis cells to 72 different antibiotics and growth-inhibiting compounds
authors: Michael D. Morrison, Patricia Fajardo-Cavazos, Wayne L. Nicholson, et al.
summary: Compares antibiotic/growth-inhibitor susceptibility (72 compounds) of B. subtilis grown on the ISS vs ground controls; finds minimal systematic changes, arguing spaceflight did not broadly increase antibiotic resistance in this assay.

title: Alterations in the Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB Gene after Cultivation in the Human Spaceflight Environment
summary: Reports that cultivation of B. subtilis aboard the ISS changes the frequency and spectrum of spontaneous rifampicin-resistance (rpoB) mutations relative to ground controls, indicating spaceflight can affect mutational outcomes.

title: Mechanotransduction in Prokaryotes: A Possible Mechanism of Spaceflight Adaptation
authors: Authors as listed on article (review/hypothesis paper)
summary: Proposes that prokaryotes have mechanotransduction-like systems and that mechanosensitive responses could explain some bacterial adaptations observed during spaceflight or microgravity analog growth.

title: Environmental dependence of competitive fitness in rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis.
summary: Shows that fitness costs/benefits of rpoB (rifampin-resistant) mutations in B. subtilis vary with environment; phenotypic consequences depend strongly on growth conditions.

title: Analysis of interactions of Salmonella type three secretion mutants with 3-D intestinal epithelial cells.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Using a 3-D organotypic intestinal epithelial model, authors show that SPI-1 T3SS is not strictly required for invasion in this 3-D model, highlighting differences between monolayer and 3-D infection assays.

title: Organotypic 3D cell culture models: using the rotating wall vessel to study host-pathogen interactions.
summary: Describes rotating wall vessel-derived 3-D organotypic cultures and their advantages for studying host–pathogen interactions under low-shear / microgravity-analog conditions.

title: Induction of attachment-independent biofilm formation and ... of Hfq expression
authors: Authors as listed on the article
organism: Bacterial biofilm models (species as in article)
summary: Focuses on Hfq-regulated processes that can induce attachment-independent biofilm-like growth; examines regulatory circuits driving biofilm physiology in the studied species.

title: Characterization of the Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi ... gene which ...
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Characterizes genetic determinants related to virulence/fitness in S. Typhi; provides genetic and phenotypic analyses that link gene(s) to host interaction properties.

title: Evaluation of microorganisms cultured from injured and regenerating rat skin
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Surveys microbes present in injured/regenerating rat skin and evaluates culturable species, their potential pathogenicity and roles during wound regeneration.

title: Transcriptional and proteomic responses of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 to spaceflight conditions involve Hfq regulation and reveal a role for oxygen.
summary: Combined transcriptomic/proteomic study showing that spaceflight alters P. aeruginosa gene and protein expression; Hfq-mediated regulation and oxygen availability are key contributors to the spaceflight response.

title: New insights into the bacterial fitness-associated mechanisms revealed by the characterization of large plasmids of an avian pathogenic E. coli
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Characterizes large plasmids from an APEC strain and links plasmid genes to virulence and fitness-associated mechanisms in extra-intestinal pathogenic E. coli.

title: Lack of norovirus replication and histo-blood group antigen expression in 3-dimensional intestinal epithelial cells
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: This 3-D intestinal epithelial model failed to support robust Norwalk virus replication under tested conditions and did not express required histo-blood group antigens for infection, showing model limitations.

title: Conservation of the low-shear modeled microgravity response in Enterobacteriaceae and analysis of the trp genes in this response.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Shows the LSMMG (low-shear modeled microgravity) transcriptional/phenotypic response is conserved across Enterobacteriaceae and implicates trp operon genes in mediating parts of that response.

title: Mimicking the host and its microenvironment in vitro for studying mucosal infections by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Review of in vitro mucosal infection models for P. aeruginosa emphasizing the importance of microenvironmental factors (oxygen, shear, mucus) for physiologically relevant host–pathogen studies.

title: Effects of Sex and Gender on Adaptation to Space: Immune System
authors: Authors as listed on article (review chapter)
summary: Review summarizing sex- and gender-related differences in immune adaptation to spaceflight, covering immunological end points and implications for astronaut health.

title: Recellularization of decellularized lung scaffolds is enhanced by dynamic suspension culture.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Demonstrates that dynamic suspension culture improves cell infiltration and distribution during recellularization of decellularized lung scaffolds versus static culture conditions.

title: Three-dimensional organotypic co-culture model of intestinal epithelial cells and macrophages to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns.
organism: Salmonella enterica / human intestinal cells & macrophages
summary: Describes and validates a 3-D co-culture model (epithelium + macrophages) for studying S. enterica colonization and host responses in a physiologically relevant context.

title: Modeling Host-Pathogen Interactions in the Context of the Microenvironment: 3-D Cell Culture Comes of Age.
authors: Authors as listed on the article (review)
summary: Review covering advances in 3-D cell culture for host–pathogen research and how microenvironmental context (oxygen, shear, ECM) shapes infection biology.

title: Evaluating the effect of spaceflight on the host–pathogen interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium
organism: Human intestinal epithelial cells / Salmonella Typhimurium
summary: Evaluates how spaceflight conditions modify Salmonella–host interactions in intestinal epithelial models, measuring invasion, gene expression and host responses changed by microgravity/spaceflight.

title: Rapid phenotypic response of LSMMG-'primed' Candida albicans.
summary: Reports rapid phenotypic changes in Candida albicans after priming under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG), including adhesion and stress-response phenotypes relevant to host colonization.

title: Spaceflight enhances cell aggregation and random budding in Candida albicans.
summary: Shows that spaceflight exposure increases cell aggregation and alters budding patterns in Candida albicans, with implications for fungal physiology during space missions.

title: Growth and antifungal resistance of the pathogenic yeast, Candida albicans, in the International Space Station: An aggregate of multiple flight experiences.
summary: Aggregates results from multiple ISS flight experiments showing effects of spaceflight on C. albicans growth and antifungal susceptibility across missions.

title: NASA GeneLab RNA-Seq Consensus Pipeline: Standardized Processing of Short-Read RNA-Seq Data
authors: Authors as listed on the article (GeneLab consortium)
summary: Describes the standardized GeneLab RNA-seq processing pipeline for short-read data to ensure reproducible, comparable transcriptomic analyses across spaceflight and ground datasets.

title: Challenges and considerations for single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics sample collection during spaceflight.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Discusses logistical and technical challenges of collecting single-cell and spatial transcriptomics samples during spaceflight and offers recommendations to preserve sample integrity.

title: Direct RNA sequencing of astronaut blood reveals spaceflight-associated m6A increases and hematopoietic transcriptional responses
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Using direct RNA sequencing, reports spaceflight-associated increases in m6A RNA modification and transcriptional shifts in hematopoietic pathways in astronaut blood samples.

title: Collection of biospecimens from the Inspiration4 mission establishes standards for the space omics and medical atlas (SOMA)
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Describes biospecimen collection protocols and standards from the Inspiration4 mission intended to support Space Omics & Medical Atlas (SOMA) data comparability and quality.

title: Microfluidics-enabled method to identify modes of Caenorhabditis elegans paralysis in four anthelmintics.
authors: Authors as listed on the article
summary: Presents a microfluidics method to classify paralysis modes of C. elegans under different anthelmintics; useful for pharmacological profiling and mode-of-action studies.

title: Multiparameter behavioral analyses provide insights...to mechanisms of cyanide resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.
summary: Develops multiparameter behavioral assays to study cyanide toxicity in C. elegans and uses genetic analyses to identify mechanisms of cyanide resistance, linking genetics to behavioral and survival outcomes.

title: Growth performance and root transcriptome remodelin...bidopsis in response to Mars-like levels of magnesium sulfate.
summary: Examines Arabidopsis growth and root transcriptome when exposed to Mars-like magnesium sulfate levels; identifies transcriptional signatures associated with MgSO4 stress and loci that modulate tolerance.

title: The 14-3-3 proteins of Arabidopsis regulate root gr...oroplast development as components of the photosensory system.
summary: Shows that 14-3-3 protein isoforms influence root growth and chloroplast development and act via photosensory pathways; uses T-DNA mutants to reveal developmental roles.

title: 14-3-3 phosphoprotein interaction networks – does isoform ...
summary: Review of 14-3-3 phosphoprotein interaction networks, discussing isoform-specific interactions and potential functional specialization.

title: Plant growth strategies are remodeled by spaceflight
summary: Recent study (2025) reporting that plant growth strategies are remodeled under spaceflight/simulated weightlessness conditions; included because the PMC link is present in your data.

title: ...preflight transcriptomes: unique responses to a novel environment.
summary: Integrative transcriptomics and proteomics study showing how Arabidopsis responds at RNA and protein levels to the spaceflight environment, highlighting pathways involved in physiological adaptation.

title: Fundamental plant biology enabled by the space shuttle.
summary: Characterizes an A. niger isolate collected from the International Space Station, including whole-genome sequencing and proteomic comparisons that reveal phenotypic and molecular differences from terrestrial strains.

title: Brachypodium distachyon Seedlings Display Accession ...
summary: Reports accession-dependent growth and transcriptomic responses in Brachypodium seedlings under defined environmental conditions; useful for understanding genetic variation in stress responses.

title: A method for preparing spaceflight RNAlater-fixed ...
summary: Describes a practical method to prepare RNAlater-fixed Arabidopsis tissue for scanning electron microscopy after spaceflight experiments, enabling better morphological preservation and imaging.

title: ARG1 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation ...
summary: Shows ARG1 is involved in plant cell physiological adaptation to spaceflight, with transcriptomic evidence that spaceflight alters cell-wall and metabolic gene expression programs.

title: A member of the CONSTANS-Like protein family is a ...
summary: Identifies a CONSTANS-like protein (OMG1) as a regulator potentially linked to reactive-oxygen-species homeostasis and spaceflight physiological adaptation in Arabidopsis.

title: HSFA2 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation ...
summary: Characterizes the role of HSFA2 (a heat-shock factor) in plant cell responses to the spaceflight environment, showing HSF network involvement in spaceflight physiological adaptation.

title: Neutrophil-to-Lymphocyte Ratio: A Biomarker to Monitor ...
summary: Reviews immune changes in spaceflight and proposes the neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) as a candidate biomarker to monitor astronaut immune status during missions.

title: Beyond Low-Earth Orbit: Characterizing Immune and ...
summary: Compares immune responses under simulated deep-space stressors (hindlimb unloading + low-dose radiation) to ISS astronaut data; highlights immune dysregulation signatures relevant to deep-space missions.

title: Immunological and hematological outcomes following ...
summary: Presents hematological and transcriptomic outcomes one week after simulated spaceflight exposures, showing persistent inflammatory and immune-related gene expression changes in spleen tissue.

title: Epigenomic Regulators Elongator Complex Subunit 2 and ...
summary: Demonstrates that disruption of epigenomic regulators (e.g., Elongator subunits) alters organ-specific DNA methylation and the spaceflight transcriptomic response in Arabidopsis.

title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress- ...
summary: Shows Arabidopsis can germinate and grow in Apollo lunar regolith samples but displays stress-associated transcriptomes and morphological stress phenotypes; informs prospects for in-situ plant cultivation on the Moon.

title: Artificial gravity partially protects spaceflight-induced ...
summary: In Drosophila, partial artificial gravity exposure mitigates some neurological deficits induced by spaceflight, suggesting countermeasure potential for gravity-related deficits.

title: Utilizing the KSC Fixation Tube to Conduct Human-Tended ...
summary: Describes use of the KSC fixation tube to enable human-tended biological experiments on short suborbital flights, documenting workflows and preservation quality for downstream molecular analyses.

title: Changes in Mouse Thymus and Spleen after Return from the STS-135 Mission in Space
summary: Reports changes in immune organs (thymus and spleen) in mice after return from STS-135, outlining immune-cell distribution and function alterations post-flight.

title: Post-Spaceflight (STS-135) Mouse Splenocytes ...
summary: Examines splenocyte functional changes after STS-135, documenting altered activation markers and cytokine responses in splenic immune cells post-spaceflight.

title: Changes in the distribution and function of leukocytes after ...
summary: Characterizes leukocyte distribution and functional changes following whole-body iron-ion irradiation, showing persistent immune alterations relevant to space radiation exposure.

title: Is spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction linked to ...
summary: Explores mechanistic links underlying spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction, integrating multiple flight datasets to identify pathways and experimental gaps.

title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the ...
summary: Multi-omics analysis showing that spaceflight activates autophagy and stress-response programs in mice, and links oxidative stress to altered metabolic and transcriptional states after flight.

title: Vive la radiorésistance!: converging research in ...
summary: Review that discusses strategies from radiobiology and aging research to enhance radioresistance for deep-space human missions; covers molecular and translational angles.

title: Proteomic Analysis of Mouse Brain Subjected to Spaceflight
summary: Quantitative proteomic profiling of mouse brains after spaceflight (STS-135) reveals changes in proteins related to oxidative stress, synaptic function, and metabolism, suggesting CNS vulnerability to space exposure.

title: Transcriptomic Effects on the Mouse Heart Following 30 ...
summary: RNA-seq analysis of hearts from female mice flown 30 days on the ISS identifies >1000 differentially expressed transcripts and implicates MAPK, PI3K-Akt and GPCR pathways in the cardiac response to spaceflight.

title: Spaceflight-Induced Gene Expression Profiles in the ...
summary: Uses spatially resolved transcriptomics to profile mouse brains subjected to spaceflight, identifying region-specific gene expression changes and potential targets for mitigation.

title: Basal signaling regulates plant growth and development
summary: 2025 genome-wide survey of PERK receptor-like kinase family across plant genomes; included because the PMC link is present in your dataset (title preserved).
